# The Workshop

The Workshop is a kids first creative studio that helps children and curious beginners turn ideas into real projects with the help of AI.

This repository contains:
- Design documents and specs (in `docs/`)
- System and role prompts (in `prompts/`)
- UI flows and wireframes (in `ui/`)
- Application code (in `app/`)
- Operations and environment notes (in `ops/`)
- Roadmap and change history (in `roadmap/`)

The Workshop is separate from Hearthlink. Hearthlink is a professional tool for orchestrating agents. The Workshop is a teaching and exploration space designed for kids first.

# Codex Runbook v1 ƒ?" The Workshop

You are Codex inside the `TheWorkshop` repo. 
You are working with a Product Manager and Lead Designer (Reed) who has defined the architecture and rules.

Your job is to keep the repo clean, traceable, and aligned with the design. 
Follow these steps **in order** unless the user tells you otherwise.

General rules:
- Always show which files you read or changed.
- Prefer editing existing files over inventing new ones.
- Respect the governance rules in `GOVERNANCE.md` and `CONTRIBUTING.md`.
- Keep prompts, specs, and code in their proper folders.
- Use small, focused commits with clear messages.

---

## STEP 0 ƒ?" Get your bearings

**Prompt to Codex:**

> Open a terminal in the current workspace and run the following commands:
>
> ```bash
> pwd
> ls
> ls docs
> ls prompts
> git status
> ```
>
> Then summarize:
> - What repo you are in
> - Which key folders exist
> - Whether there are uncommitted changes

---

## STEP 1 ƒ?" Load the project rules into your head

**Prompt to Codex:**

> Open and read the following files and summarize their rules and expectations:
> - `README.md`
> - `GOVERNANCE.md`
> - `CONTRIBUTING.md`
> - `docs/WORKSHOP_ATLAS.md`
> - `docs/PEDAGOGY_LOOP.md`
> - `docs/SAFETY_CONTRACT.md`
>
> In your own words, explain:
> - What The Workshop is for
> - Who it serves
> - The non negotiable rules for features, prompts, and changes
> - The purpose of Stations and the learning loop
>
> Do not edit any files in this step. This is orientation only.

---

## STEP 2 ƒ?" Align station specs

Goal: make sure each Station spec is fully aligned with the design vision and is self contained.

**Prompt to Codex:**

> Open the following files:
> - `docs/stations/IDEA_STATION.md`
> - `docs/stations/BUILD_STATION.md`
> - `docs/stations/TEST_STATION.md`
> - `docs/stations/MEMORY_STATION.md`
>
> For each file:
> - Ensure it includes these sections: Purpose, Role in the learning loop, Inputs, Outputs, User experience, Safety behavior, Example child dialogue.
> - Rewrite or extend the content so it reflects a Starship Shipyard theme with the Station names:
>   - Idea Station ƒ+' Design Dock
>   - Build Station ƒ+' Assembly Bay
>   - Test Station ƒ+' Diagnostics Corridor
>   - Memory Station ƒ+' Stellar Archive
> - Make the language clear, concrete, and kid friendly without being childish.
>
> When you are done, show me a diff style summary of what changed in each file, but do not commit yet.

After Codex completes edits and shows changes, you run:

```bash
git diff docs/stations
```

If you are happy with the changes:

```bash
git add docs/stations
git commit -m "Refine Workshop Station specs for v0 (Shipyard theme)"
```

---

## STEP 3 ƒ?" Align Station system prompts

Goal: have clean, consistent system prompts for each Station that match the specs.

**Prompt to Codex:**

> Open the following prompt files:
> - `prompts/stations/idea_station_system.txt`
> - `prompts/stations/build_station_system.txt`
> - `prompts/stations/test_station_system.txt`
> - `prompts/stations/memory_station_system.txt`
>
> For each file:
> - Make sure the prompt:
>   - Names the Station and its Shipyard alias
>   - States the Station's job in one or two sentences
>   - References the five step loop: Ask, Reflect, Plan, Act, Review (with emphasis appropriate to the Station)
>   - Mentions the Safety Contract and how the Station uses it
>   - Includes 4ƒ?"6 short, clear behavioral rules
> - Keep the style simple and direct, suitable for use as a system prompt.
>
> Show me the full contents of each file after editing, and do not commit yet.

After Codex updates them and you are satisfied:

```bash
git add prompts/stations
git commit -m "Align Station system prompts with v0 specs"
```

---

## STEP 4 ƒ?" Flesh out the data model

Goal: define a concrete v0 data model that supports Projects, Steps, and StationState.

**Prompt to Codex:**

> Open `docs/DATA_MODEL.md`.
>
> Expand it into a clear v0 spec that includes:
> - A short description of the data model goals.
> - Definitions for:
>   - User
>   - Project
>   - Step
>   - StationState
> - For each type, list fields with:
>   - Name
>   - Type
>   - Description
> - Include one or two small JSON examples that show:
>   - A Project with a few Steps
>   - How StationState is used to track work in a Station.
>
> Keep it implementation neutral (no specific database) but concrete enough that a backend can be implemented from this doc.
>
> Show me the full file content when you are done, and do not commit yet.

After review:

```bash
git add docs/DATA_MODEL.md
git commit -m "Define v0 data model for Projects, Steps, and StationState"
```

---

## STEP 5 ƒ?" Describe onboarding and project creation flows

Goal: have solid textual flow specs before we touch any UI code.

**Prompt to Codex:**

> Open:
> - `docs/flows/ONBOARDING_FLOW.md`
> - `docs/flows/PROJECT_CREATION_FLOW.md`
>
> For `ONBOARDING_FLOW.md`:
> - Write a step by step narrative of what a brand new child user experiences:
>   - First launch
>   - Meeting The Workshop
>   - Being introduced to Stations
>   - Creating their first Project
>
> For `PROJECT_CREATION_FLOW.md`:
> - Describe how an existing user:
>   - Creates a new Project from the main view
>   - Moves into the Idea Station
>   - Comes out with a Project summary and a first set of Steps
>
> In each file, separate the flow into clearly numbered steps, and call out which Station is active at each step.
>
> Show me both files when you are done, and do not commit yet.

After review:

```bash
git add docs/flows/ONBOARDING_FLOW.md docs/flows/PROJECT_CREATION_FLOW.md
git commit -m "Define onboarding and project creation flows for The Workshop"
```

---

## STEP 6 ƒ?" Create the first feature spec file

Goal: start the FEATURE-WS tracking discipline from the beginning.

**Prompt to Codex:**

> Create a new file `docs/features/FEATURE-WS-0001-idea-station-v1.md` using `docs/features/FEATURE_TEMPLATE.md` as a base.
>
> Fill it out to describe the v1 implementation of the Idea Station (Design Dock):
> - Its purpose and scope
> - What is in scope for v1 and what is explicitly out of scope
> - Affected Stations (only IdeaStation for this feature)
> - User type (Kid first, Mentor second)
> - Acceptance criteria for a minimal working Idea Station
>
> Show me the full file content when you are done.

After review:

```bash
git add docs/features/FEATURE-WS-0001-idea-station-v1.md
git commit -m "Add feature spec FEATURE-WS-0001 for Idea Station v1"
```

---

## STEP 7 ƒ?" Update roadmap and changelog

Goal: tie the design work into the project history.

**Prompt to Codex:**

> Open:
> - `roadmap/ROADMAP_V0_V1.md`
> - `roadmap/CHANGELOG.md`
>
> In `ROADMAP_V0_V1.md`:
> - Add a short list of milestones for v0:
>   - Station specs and prompts finalized
>   - Data model defined
>   - Onboarding and project flows defined
>   - Idea Station v1 implemented
>
> In `CHANGELOG.md`:
> - Add entries for today capturing the work done so far (station specs, prompts, data model, flows, first feature spec). You can leave the exact date for the user to fill in.
>
> Show me both files when you are done, and do not commit yet.

After review:

```bash
git add roadmap/ROADMAP_V0_V1.md roadmap/CHANGELOG.md
git commit -m "Update roadmap and changelog for initial design work"
```

---

## STEP 8 ƒ?" Prepare for future app scaffolding

Goal: set the stage without bloating the dev server yet.

**Prompt to Codex:**

> Open `app/frontend/README.md` and `app/backend/README.md`.
>
> In `app/frontend/README.md`, write a brief plan for a local first desktop style app using web tech, including:
> - Likely choice of framework (for example, React with Vite)
> - High level structure of pages or main screens based on the flows
> - A note that v0 will not implement multiplayer
>
> In `app/backend/README.md`, write a brief plan for a simple backend that:
> - Stores Projects, Steps, and StationState locally
> - Could later be swapped for a hosted API without breaking the app
>
> Show me both files when you are done.

After review:

```bash
git add app/frontend/README.md app/backend/README.md
git commit -m "Outline frontend and backend approach for v0 Workshop app"
```

---

## STEP 9 ƒ?" Sanity check and status

**Prompt to Codex:**

> Run:
> ```bash
> git status
> ```
> Then summarize:
> - What has been committed in this session
> - What design pieces are now in place
> - What you recommend as the next implementation step (likely starting small with Idea Station UI or storage)

This completes Runbook v1.

Future runbooks will cover:
- Implementing a minimal UI shell for the four Stations
- Adding a simple local file or JSON based storage layer
- Wiring Station prompts into an AI backend
- Gradual steps toward a real child facing prototype

# The Workshop

The Workshop is a kids first creative studio that teaches how to build things step by step with the help of AI.

It is not a code editor and not a full developer environment.  
Its primary purpose is to help children (and curious beginners) learn how to:

- Shape ideas  
- Break ideas into steps  
- Test and question their creations  
- Keep track of their projects over time  

This repo will contain the design documents, prompts, and architecture for The Workshop.

# Pedagogy Loop

All Stations use a common five step learning loop:

1. Ask
2. Reflect
3. Plan
4. Act
5. Review

Each Station emphasizes different parts of this loop. The loop is designed to keep the child active, not passive, and to build real thinking skills.

# Safety Contract

The Workshop is designed for children and beginners. It must remain safe, honest, and respectful.

Core rules:
- No help with self harm, violence, abuse, or illegal activity.
- No pretending to be a doctor, therapist, lawyer, or authority.
- Truth over coolness: guesses are labeled as guesses.
- Kindness first: no shaming, encouragement of effort over perfection.

Each Station integrates these rules into its own behavior.

-
-Purpose:
-- Help the child turn a vague idea into a clear, buildable project.
-
-Focus in the Pedagogy Loop:
-- Ask
-- Reflect
-- Plan
-
-This spec will be expanded with inputs, outputs, and example dialogues.
+# Idea Station (Design Dock)
+
+Internal name: IdeaStation  
+Theme name (Starship Shipyard): Design Dock
+
+## Purpose
+- Turn a spark into a clear mission the child can actually build.
+- Name what success looks like in kid-friendly, concrete terms.
+
+## Role in the learning loop
+- Ask: draw out the dream, goal, and why it matters.
+- Reflect: check if the idea feels doable and exciting.
+- Plan: sketch a simple first flight path (early steps).
+
+## Inputs
+- Child’s idea in their own words (even if messy).
+- Interests, constraints (time, tools), and any inspiration.
+- Safety Contract reminders if topics feel risky.
+
+## Outputs
+- A short mission brief: goal, audience, and success picture.
+- 3–5 starter steps sized for a beginner.
+- A one-line project name the child likes.
+
+## User experience
+- Feels like stepping onto a ship’s Design Dock: lots of “what if?” questions, gentle nudges, and visual metaphors (cargo, crew, mission).
+- Uses open questions, quick reflections, and suggests only a few choices at a time.
+- Ends with the child approving the mission brief before leaving.
+
+## Safety behavior
+- Filters out harmful/unsafe topics; redirects to safe, positive ideas.
+- Labels guesses, keeps tone kind, and never pretends to be an authority.
+- Encourages doable scopes to prevent frustration.
+
+## Example child dialogue
+- Child: “I want to make a comic about a robot dog.”
+- Design Dock: “Cool mission! Who is the comic for, and what does the robot dog need to do in the first scene?”
+- Child: “It’s for my friends. The dog saves a kite.”
+- Design Dock: “Great. Mission brief: ‘Robot dog rescues a kite for friends.’ First steps: 1) Pick the dog’s look, 2) Sketch the kite trouble, 3) Write 4 speech bubbles. Want to launch with these?”
*** End Patch

+# Build Station (Assembly Bay)
+
+Internal name: BuildStation  
+Theme name (Starship Shipyard): Assembly Bay
+
+## Purpose
+- Turn the mission brief into a step-by-step build plan.
+- Help the child make steady progress with small, doable tasks.
+
+## Role in the learning loop
+- Plan: lay out parts and sequence the build.
+- Act: guide the child through the next clear action.
+- Review: light check after each mini-task to keep quality up.
+
+## Inputs
+- Mission brief and starter steps from the Design Dock.
+- Current status of steps (done, in progress, blocked).
+- Available time, tools, and any examples the child has.
+
+## Outputs
+- An ordered list of build steps sized for beginners.
+- A current “next action” with a suggested time box.
+- Quick check notes on what was finished and what to improve later.
+
+## User experience
+- Feels like an Assembly Bay with parts laid out; the Station highlights one part at a time.
+- Uses short, direct instructions and mini-celebrations for progress.
+- Offers options when the child is stuck (break a step smaller, swap order, or ask for a hint).
+
+## Safety behavior
+- Keeps scope realistic to avoid overwhelm; reminds the child to take breaks.
+- Avoids unsafe tool use; redirects to safe materials and online resources.
+- Encourages asking for help if frustrated; keeps tone calm and supportive.
+
+## Example child dialogue
+- Child: “I need to draw my robot dog hero.”
+- Assembly Bay: “Let’s do just the head first. Draw the head shape and one fun feature. Ready to try that for 5 minutes?”
+- Child: “Okay, I’ll add big goggles.”
+- Assembly Bay: “Nice pick! Mark head sketch as done, then we’ll add the ears next.”
*** End Patch

-# Test Station (Diagnostics Corridor)
-
-Internal name: TestStation
-Theme name (Starship Shipyard): Diagnostics Corridor
-
-Purpose:
-- Teach the habit of testing and questioning.
-
-Focus in the Pedagogy Loop:
-- Ask
-- Act
-- Review
-
-This spec will be expanded with inputs, outputs, and example dialogues.
+# Test Station (Diagnostics Corridor)
+
+Internal name: TestStation  
+Theme name (Starship Shipyard): Diagnostics Corridor
+
+## Purpose
+- Teach the habit of testing, questioning, and fixing with confidence.
+- Help the child notice what works, what breaks, and why.
+
+## Role in the learning loop
+- Ask: what should this part do, and does it actually do it?
+- Act: run a quick check or try it out.
+- Review: capture what passed, what failed, and next fixes.
+
+## Inputs
+- The current artifact (drawing, writing, code, craft).
+- Expected behaviors or goals from the mission brief.
+- Any known issues or worries from the child.
+
+## Outputs
+- A small test checklist with kid-friendly wording.
+- Observations (pass/fail/odd) and a priority list of fixes.
+- A short retest plan for the next visit to the Assembly Bay.
+
+## User experience
+- Feels like walking down a Diagnostics Corridor with lit-up panels showing checks.
+- Uses simple “Does it do X? Yes/No/Kind of” questions.
+- Celebrates discoveries, not just passes; keeps tone curious and calm.
+
+## Safety behavior
+- Frames issues as learnings, not failures; no shaming language.
+- Avoids unsafe experiments; keeps suggestions within safe materials and topics.
+- Labels guesses; reminds the child to ask an adult when unsure.
+
+## Example child dialogue
+- Child: “My comic page looks crowded.”
+- Diagnostics Corridor: “Let’s test readability. Can you follow the panels in order without confusion?”
+- Child: “Panel 2 and 3 feel mixed up.”
+- Diagnostics Corridor: “Noted. Fix idea: add a small arrow between panels 2 and 3. After that, retest: can you read it smoothly?”
*** End Patch

+# Memory Station (Stellar Archive)
+
+Internal name: MemoryStation  
+Theme name (Starship Shipyard): Stellar Archive
+
+## Purpose
+- Keep a living record of the mission so far.
+- Help the child reuse past wins and spot patterns.
+
+## Role in the learning loop
+- Reflect: what did we try, and what worked?
+- Review: what’s still open, and what should we carry forward?
+- Ask: what should we remember next time before we build?
+
+## Inputs
+- Project log: mission brief, steps, test notes, and snapshots of work.
+- Child’s reflections (“I liked…”, “I’d change…”).
+- Milestones or moments they want to remember.
+
+## Outputs
+- A clear recap (wins, blockers, next focus).
+- Highlighted reminders for the next Station visit.
+- A timeline entry that feels like a captain’s log.
+
+## User experience
+- Feels like entering the Stellar Archive: shelves of glowing logs and artifacts.
+- Gathers reflections with quick prompts, then shows a tidy summary.
+- Surfaces callbacks: “Last time you liked X; want to repeat it?” or “You paused at step 3.”
+
+## Safety behavior
+- Keeps personal details minimal; focuses on project facts and feelings.
+- Encourages honest reflection without blame; keeps tone kind and balanced.
+- Reminds the child to share only what they are comfortable archiving.
+
+## Example child dialogue
+- Child: “I fixed the panel order and it reads better.”
+- Stellar Archive: “Logged: ‘Panel order fixed; flow is clear.’ What should we watch for next time?”
+- Child: “Keep speech bubbles small.”
+- Stellar Archive: “Noted. Reminder set: ‘Check bubble size before final inking.’ Ready to send this to the Assembly Bay?”
*** End Patch

*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: docs/DATA_MODEL.md
@@
-# Data Model (v0 sketch)
-
-Minimal objects:
-
-- User
-- Project
-- Step
-- StationState
-
-This document will evolve as the implementation takes shape.
+# Data Model (v0)
+
+## Goals
+- Provide a minimal, shared shape for storing Workshop data across Stations.
+- Stay implementation neutral (files, local DB, hosted API can all use these shapes).
+- Keep fields small and readable for kids-first workflows while leaving room to extend.
+
+## Core types and fields
+
+### User
+Fields:
+- id (string): Stable unique id (e.g., UUID).
+- displayName (string): The name shown in the app.
+- role (enum): "kid" | "mentor" | "admin" (optional roles for supervision).
+- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): When the user was created.
+- lastActiveAt (datetime ISO-8601, optional): Last activity timestamp.
+
+### Project
+Fields:
+- id (string): Unique project id.
+- ownerId (string): User.id of the creator/owner.
+- title (string): Short, child-chosen project name.
+- description (string): Brief mission summary from the Design Dock.
+- status (enum): "draft" | "in_progress" | "paused" | "completed" | "archived".
+- currentStation (enum): "idea" | "build" | "test" | "memory" (where the child is now).
+- steps (array<Step>): Ordered list of steps for this project.
+- stationStates (object<StationState>): Map keyed by stationKey for per-station context.
+- tags (array<string>, optional): Simple labels (e.g., "comic", "robot").
+- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): Creation timestamp.
+- updatedAt (datetime ISO-8601): Last modification timestamp.
+
+### Step
+Fields:
+- id (string): Unique step id.
+- projectId (string): Parent Project.id.
+- title (string): Short action the child can do.
+- summary (string, optional): Extra guidance for the step.
+- status (enum): "todo" | "in_progress" | "blocked" | "done".
+- order (number): Display/order index within the project.
+- originStation (enum, optional): "idea" | "build" | "test" | "memory" (where it was created).
+- acceptanceCriteria (string, optional): How we know this step is done.
+- notes (string, optional): Quick notes or hints.
+- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): Creation timestamp.
+- updatedAt (datetime ISO-8601): Last modification timestamp.
+
+### StationState
+Represents the latest context and artifacts for a Project inside one Station.
+Fields:
+- id (string): Unique station state id.
+- projectId (string): Parent Project.id.
+- stationKey (enum): "idea" | "build" | "test" | "memory".
+- inputs (object): Station-specific inputs (e.g., child goal, constraints).
+- outputs (object): Station-specific outputs (e.g., mission brief, test findings).
+- activeStepIds (array<string>): Step ids currently in focus here.
+- reflections (array<object>): Time-stamped notes or learnings (text + createdAt).

# Data Model (v0)

## Goals
- Provide a minimal, shared shape for storing Workshop data across Stations.
- Stay implementation neutral (files, local DB, hosted API can all use these shapes).
- Keep fields small and readable for kids-first workflows while leaving room to extend.

## Core types and fields

### User
Fields:
- id (string): Stable unique id (e.g., UUID).
- displayName (string): The name shown in the app.
- role (enum): "kid" | "mentor" | "admin" (optional roles for supervision).
- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): When the user was created.
- lastActiveAt (datetime ISO-8601, optional): Last activity timestamp.

### Project
Fields:
- id (string): Unique project id.
- ownerId (string): User.id of the creator/owner.
- title (string): Short, child-chosen project name.
- description (string): Brief mission summary from the Design Dock.
- status (enum): "draft" | "in_progress" | "paused" | "completed" | "archived".
- currentStation (enum): "idea" | "build" | "test" | "memory" (where the child is now).
- steps (array<Step>): Ordered list of steps for this project.
- stationStates (object<StationState>): Map keyed by stationKey for per-station context.
- tags (array<string>, optional): Simple labels (e.g., "comic", "robot").
- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): Creation timestamp.
- updatedAt (datetime ISO-8601): Last modification timestamp.

### Step
Fields:
- id (string): Unique step id.
- projectId (string): Parent Project.id.
- title (string): Short action the child can do.
- summary (string, optional): Extra guidance for the step.
- status (enum): "todo" | "in_progress" | "blocked" | "done".
- order (number): Display/order index within the project.
- originStation (enum, optional): "idea" | "build" | "test" | "memory" (where it was created).
- acceptanceCriteria (string, optional): How we know this step is done.
- notes (string, optional): Quick notes or hints.
- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): Creation timestamp.
- updatedAt (datetime ISO-8601): Last modification timestamp.

### StationState
Represents the latest context and artifacts for a Project inside one Station.
Fields:
- id (string): Unique station state id.
- projectId (string): Parent Project.id.
- stationKey (enum): "idea" | "build" | "test" | "memory".
- inputs (object): Station-specific inputs (e.g., child goal, constraints).
- outputs (object): Station-specific outputs (e.g., mission brief, test findings).
- activeStepIds (array<string>): Step ids currently in focus here.
- reflections (array<object>): Time-stamped notes or learnings (text + createdAt).
- lastVisitedAt (datetime ISO-8601): Last time this Station was used for the project.
- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): Creation timestamp.
- updatedAt (datetime ISO-8601): Last modification timestamp.

## Examples

### Project with Steps
```json
{
  "id": "proj_123",
  "ownerId": "user_001",
  "title": "Robot Dog Comic",
  "description": "A comic where a robot dog rescues a kite for friends.",
  "status": "in_progress",
  "currentStation": "build",
  "tags": ["comic", "robot"],
  "steps": [
    {
      "id": "step_1",
      "projectId": "proj_123",
      "title": "Sketch robot dog head",
      "status": "done",
      "order": 1,
      "originStation": "build",
      "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:10:00Z",
      "updatedAt": "2025-12-04T00:25:00Z"
    },
    {
      "id": "step_2",
      "projectId": "proj_123",
      "title": "Draw kite in trouble",
      "status": "in_progress",
      "order": 2,
      "originStation": "idea",
      "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:26:00Z",
      "updatedAt": "2025-12-04T00:40:00Z"
    },
    {
      "id": "step_3",
      "projectId": "proj_123",
      "title": "Write 4 speech bubbles",
      "status": "todo",
      "order": 3,
      "originStation": "idea",
      "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:27:00Z",
      "updatedAt": "2025-12-04T00:27:00Z"
    }
  ],
  "stationStates": {},
  "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:05:00Z",
  "updatedAt": "2025-12-04T00:40:00Z"
}
```

### StationState (Design Dock example)
```json
{
  "id": "state_idea_proj_123",
  "projectId": "proj_123",
  "stationKey": "idea",
  "inputs": {
    "childGoal": "Make a comic for friends",
    "constraints": {
      "timeMinutes": 60,
      "tools": ["paper", "markers"]
    }
  },
  "outputs": {
    "missionBrief": "Robot dog rescues a kite for friends.",
    "projectName": "Robot Dog Comic",
    "starterSteps": ["Draw head", "Draw kite trouble", "Write 4 bubbles"]
  },
  "activeStepIds": ["step_2"],
  "reflections": [
    {
      "note": "Drawing big goggles makes the dog look friendlier.",
      "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:30:00Z"
    }
  ],
  "lastVisitedAt": "2025-12-04T00:35:00Z",
  "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:05:00Z",
  "updatedAt": "2025-12-04T00:35:00Z"
}
```

@@
-# Onboarding Flow (v0 sketch)
-
-Goal: introduce a new child user to The Workshop and the idea of Stations.
+# Onboarding Flow (v0)
+
+Goal: introduce a brand new child user to The Workshop, the Stations, and help them launch their first Project.
+
+## Steps
+1) First launch splash (Station: none)
+   - The app opens with a friendly welcome screen that says “Welcome aboard The Workshop” with a brief line: “A place to turn your ideas into real projects, step by step.”
+   - Shows two buttons: “Start” and “What is The Workshop?” (an optional info panel).
+
+2) Name yourself (Station: none)
+   - Prompt: “What should we call you?” with a single text field (displayName) and a clear “Continue” button.
+   - Safety hint: “Keep it friendly; no last names needed.”
+
+3) Meet The Workshop (Station: none)
+   - A short 3-card intro carousel (skippable):
+     - Card 1: “Stations are rooms that help you think, build, test, and remember.”
+     - Card 2: “You choose the mission; we keep you safe and kind.”
+     - Card 3: “You’ll start at the Design Dock to shape your idea.”
+   - Button: “Let’s visit the Stations.”
+
+4) Stations overview (Station: overview)
+   - Simple grid or list with brief kid-friendly blurbs and icons:
+     - Design Dock (Idea Station): “Shape your mission.”
+     - Assembly Bay (Build Station): “Build one small part at a time.”
+     - Diagnostics Corridor (Test Station): “Check what works and fix what doesn’t.”
+     - Stellar Archive (Memory Station): “Remember wins, lessons, and next steps.”
+   - Button: “Create my first project.”
+
+5) Start first project setup (Station: Design Dock intro)
+   - Prompt: “What do you want to make?” with an open text field for the raw idea.
+   - Optional prompts: interests, time available, tools on hand.
+   - Safety reminder displayed subtly: “We keep ideas safe, kind, and honest.”
+
+6) Shape the mission (Station: Design Dock)
+   - Guided questions: audience, goal, why it matters to them.
+   - The system drafts a short mission brief; the child can edit/approve.
+   - Shows a one-line project name suggestion the child can accept or change.
+
+7) Create starter steps (Station: Design Dock)
+   - Suggests 3–5 tiny starter steps; child can reorder or tweak labels.
+   - Confirms scope is doable (time/tools check); offers to shrink steps if needed.
+
+8) Confirm and launch (Station: Design Dock → ready state)
+   - Summary screen: project name, mission brief, first steps.
+   - Button: “Launch project” which saves Project and steps, sets currentStation to Design Dock or Assembly Bay depending on next action chosen.
+   - Offer: “Jump to Assembly Bay to start building” or “Save and explore later.”
+
+9) Wrap-up / handoff (Station: optional next)
+   - If continuing: moves to Assembly Bay with the first step selected.
+   - If pausing: returns to a simple Home with the project pinned and a prompt to resume later.
*** End Patch

*** Update File: docs/flows/PROJECT_CREATION_FLOW.md
@@
-# Project Creation Flow (v0 sketch)
-
-Goal: help the child create a new project and move naturally from Idea Station to Build Station.
+# Project Creation Flow (v0)
+
+Goal: help an existing user start a new Project, move through the Idea Station (Design Dock), and leave with a project summary plus first steps.
+
+## Steps
+1) Start from Home/Main view (Station: none)
+   - User sees recent Projects list and a clear “New Project” button.
+   - Clicking “New Project” opens a lightweight modal or page to begin.
+
+2) Capture the spark (Station: Design Dock intro)
+   - Prompt: “What do you want to make?” with open text.
+   - Optional quick toggles: time available today, tools on hand, who it’s for.
+
+3) Clarify the mission (Station: Design Dock)
+   - Questions: audience, goal, why it matters; surface the Safety Contract briefly.
+   - System drafts a mission brief; user can edit and approve.
+   - Suggest a project name; allow quick rename.
+
+4) Draft starter steps (Station: Design Dock)
+   - Suggest 3–5 small steps sized for beginners; show time/effort hints.
+   - Allow reordering and editing; ensure at least one clear first step.
+
+5) Review and confirm (Station: Design Dock → ready state)
+   - Summary screen: project name, mission brief, starter steps.
+   - Choices:
+     - “Start building now” → continue to Assembly Bay with first step selected.
+     - “Save for later” → saves Project and returns to Home with new entry pinned.
+
+6) Handoff to build (Station: Assembly Bay entry)
+   - If “Start building now”: loads Assembly Bay with the first step active and a short welcome: “Let’s tackle this step first.”
+   - Shows next actions and a quick link back to the mission brief if needed.
*** End Patch

{"command":"@'
# Project Creation Flow (v0)

Goal: help an existing user start a new Project, move through the Idea Station (Design Dock), and leave with a project summary plus first steps.

## Steps
1) Start from Home/Main view (Station: none)
   - User sees recent Projects list and a clear "New Project" button.
   - Clicking "New Project" opens a lightweight modal or page to begin.

2) Capture the spark (Station: Design Dock intro)
   - Prompt: "What do you want to make?" with open text.
   - Optional quick toggles: time available today, tools on hand, who it's for.

3) Clarify the mission (Station: Design Dock)
   - Questions: audience, goal, why it matters; surface the Safety Contract briefly.
   - System drafts a mission brief; user can edit and approve.
   - Suggest a project name; allow quick rename.

4) Draft starter steps (Station: Design Dock)
   - Suggest 3-5 small steps sized for beginners; show time/effort hints.
   - Allow reordering and editing; ensure at least one clear first step.

5) Review and confirm (Station: Design Dock -> ready state)
   - Summary screen: project name, mission brief, starter steps.
   - Choices:
     - "Start building now" -> continue to Assembly Bay with first step selected.
     - "Save for later" -> saves Project and returns to Home with new entry pinned.

6) Handoff to build (Station: Assembly Bay entry)
   - If "Start building now": loads Assembly Bay with the first step active and a short welcome: "Let's tackle this step first."
   - Shows next actions and a quick link back to the mission brief if needed.
'@ | Set-Content -Path docs/flows/PROJECT_CREATION_FLOW.md"}

payload.arguments:
{"command":"@'
# FEATURE-WS-0001 Idea Station v1 (Design Dock)

## Summary
A minimal Idea Station (Design Dock) that helps a child turn a spark into a clear, buildable mission with a mission brief, project name, and 3-5 starter steps.

## Scope

- In scope:
  - Collecting the child’s idea, audience, and goal with kid-friendly prompts.
  - Generating a concise mission brief the child can edit and approve.
  - Suggesting a project name the child can accept or tweak.
  - Producing 3-5 tiny starter steps sized for beginners, editable and reorderable.
  - Basic Safety Contract checks (redirect unsafe topics, label guesses, keep tone kind).
  - Storing the Project with mission brief, name, and starter steps.
- Out of scope:
  - Multiplayer or co-editing.
  - Rich media uploads or drawing tools inside the Design Dock.
  - Advanced AI planning beyond short starter steps.
  - Cross-project templates or idea libraries.

## Affected Stations

- IdeaStation

## User Type

- Kid (primary)
- Mentor (secondary, light guidance only)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] A child can enter an idea and audience/goal details and see them reflected in a generated mission brief they can edit.
- [ ] The Station suggests a project name the child can accept or change.
- [ ] The Station suggests 3-5 small starter steps sized for beginners; the child can reorder and edit them.
- [ ] Safety behaviors apply: blocks/redirects unsafe topics, labels guesses, tone stays kind.
- [ ] Saving creates a Project with mission brief, project name, and starter steps persisted and ready for the next Station.

# FEATURE-WS-0001 Idea Station v1 (Design Dock)

## Summary
A minimal Idea Station (Design Dock) that helps a child turn a spark into a clear, buildable mission with a mission brief, project name, and 3-5 starter steps.

## Scope

- In scope:
  - Collecting the child's idea, audience, and goal with kid-friendly prompts.
  - Generating a concise mission brief the child can edit and approve.
  - Suggesting a project name the child can accept or tweak.
  - Producing 3-5 tiny starter steps sized for beginners, editable and reorderable.
  - Basic Safety Contract checks (redirect unsafe topics, label guesses, keep tone kind).
  - Storing the Project with mission brief, name, and starter steps.
- Out of scope:
  - Multiplayer or co-editing.
  - Rich media uploads or drawing tools inside the Design Dock.
  - Advanced AI planning beyond short starter steps.
  - Cross-project templates or idea libraries.

## Affected Stations

- IdeaStation

## User Type

- Kid (primary)
- Mentor (secondary, light guidance only)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] A child can enter an idea and audience/goal details and see them reflected in a generated mission brief they can edit.
- [ ] The Station suggests a project name the child can accept or change.
- [ ] The Station suggests 3-5 small starter steps sized for beginners; the child can reorder and edit them.
- [ ] Safety behaviors apply: blocks/redirects unsafe topics, labels guesses, tone stays kind.
- [ ] Saving creates a Project with mission brief, project name, and starter steps persisted and ready for the next Station.

## Links

- Related prompts: prompts/stations/idea_station_system.txt
- Related UI flows: docs/flows/PROJECT_CREATION_FLOW.md, docs/flows/ONBOARDING_FLOW.md
- Related issues or tickets: (TBD)

-# Frontend
-
-This folder will contain the Workshop frontend application.
+# Frontend (v0 plan)
+
+Goal: local-first, desktop-style app built with familiar web tech.
+
+## Stack
+- React + Vite for fast dev and simple bundling.
+- TypeScript for type safety.
+- Lightweight state management (React Query or Zustand) to keep fetch/cache simple.
+
+## Main screens (aligned to flows)
+- Home: recent Projects, “New Project” button, entry to Stations.
+- Design Dock (Idea Station): capture spark, audience/goal, generate mission brief, suggest project name, draft 3–5 starter steps.
+- Assembly Bay (Build Station): ordered steps list, active step detail, quick progress updates.
+- Diagnostics Corridor (Test Station): simple test checklist view, log of findings/fixes.
+- Stellar Archive (Memory Station): recap timeline, reminders, reflections.
+- Settings/Help: user display name, safety notice, onboarding recap.
+
+## Local-first notes
+- Store data locally first (e.g., file/IndexedDB) with a clean data API layer so a future hosted backend can be swapped in.
+- v0 will not implement multiplayer; design UI assuming single user on one device.
*** End Patch

-# Backend
-
-This folder will contain any backend services needed for The Workshop.
+# Backend (v0 plan)
+
+Goal: simple, local-first storage for Projects, Steps, and StationState with an interface that can swap to a hosted API later.
+
+## Approach
+- Provide a thin data service with CRUD for User, Project, Step, and StationState using the shapes in `docs/DATA_MODEL.md`.
+- Default implementation: local storage layer (e.g., files/IndexedDB/SQLite) with clear interfaces.
+- Keep transport-agnostic contracts (e.g., repository or service interfaces) so a remote API client can replace the local adapter without UI changes.
+- Include basic migrations/versioning for stored data to evolve the model safely.
+
+## Responsibilities (v0)
+- Create/read/update/delete Projects, Steps, StationState for a single local user.
+- Persist mission briefs, starter steps, and per-Station context.
+- Expose simple query helpers (e.g., list projects, list steps by project, get station state).
+- Enforce Safety Contract at data boundaries where applicable (e.g., filter/flag unsafe content fields before save if needed).
+
+## Out of scope (v0)
+- Multiplayer or real-time sync.
+- Authentication and roles beyond a single local profile.
+- Hosted API deployment (kept as a future adapter).
*** End Patch

## My request for Codex:
You are Codex inside the TheWorkshop repo.
The design docs, data model, and flows are already in place.
Now you will start a minimal implementation for the Idea Station (Design Dock) UI and a local storage adapter, staying within the existing architecture and rules.

Goals for this step:

Add TypeScript types for the core data model on the frontend, matching docs/DATA_MODEL.md.

Create a simple local storage adapter for Projects and Steps.

Create a first pass UI component for the Idea Station (Design Dock) that:

Shows a mission brief.

Lets the child define a project summary.

Lets the child add a few starter steps.

Saves the project locally through the storage adapter.

Follow these constraints:

Do not scaffold a full build system or run external CLIs.
Create code files under app/frontend/ so they can be wired into a framework later.

Keep dependencies zero for now. Use pure TypeScript and React style JSX, but do not modify any package.json.

Keep everything small and readable. This is a first prototype, not final production code.

Data model types

Create a new file:

app/frontend/src/domain/project.ts

In that file, define TypeScript interfaces for:

User

Project

Step

StationState

Base the fields on docs/DATA_MODEL.md. Add sensible optional fields if needed, but keep it minimal.

Local storage adapter

Create:

app/frontend/src/storage/localProjectStore.ts

Implement a simple local storage based adapter that:

Stores an array of Project objects under a single key, for example "workshop_projects".

## My request for Codex:
You are Codex inside the TheWorkshop repo.
The Station specs, data model, flows, and first UI and storage for the Idea Station are now in place.

Your next task is to align and finalize the Station system prompts so they match the current design.

Open these files:

prompts/stations/idea_station_system.txt

prompts/stations/build_station_system.txt

prompts/stations/test_station_system.txt

prompts/stations/memory_station_system.txt

For each file:

Make sure the prompt:

Names the Station and its Shipyard alias:

Idea Station → Design Dock

Build Station → Assembly Bay

Test Station → Diagnostics Corridor

Memory Station → Stellar Archive

States, in one or two sentences, what that Station is responsible for.

References the five step learning loop:

Ask

Reflect

Plan

Act

Review
with emphasis appropriate to the Station.

Explicitly references the Safety Contract and how this Station should respond to unsafe or harmful requests.

Contains 4 to 6 short behavioral rules as bullet points, focused on:

Tone

Question style

How to involve the child

How to handle uncertainty

Ensure the language is simple, direct, and suitable for use as a system prompt.

When you are done:

For each file, briefly summarize how you changed or clarified it.

Then show the full contents of all four prompt files.

Do not run git add or git commit. Leave that to the user.

summary.text:
**Drafting system prompt outlines**

I'm creating clear, simple system prompts for each station highlighting their key responsibilities and aligning with the five-step learning loop (Ask, Reflect, Plan, Act, Review). Each prompt will mention the Safety Contract with instructions for handling unsafe content and include 4-6 friendly bullet rules emphasizing scope, tone, and steps management. Next, I'll apply patches to replace existing content accordingly.

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: prompts/stations/idea_station_system.txt
@@
-You are the Idea Station, also called the Design Dock. Help the child turn a vague idea into a clear project using the five step loop: Ask, Reflect, Plan, Act, Review.
+You are the Idea Station (Design Dock). Your job is to turn the child's spark into a clear mission brief and 3-5 starter steps. Use the learning loop with emphasis on Ask, Reflect, Plan (lightly touch Act, Review).
+Safety Contract: if a request is unsafe (self-harm, violence, abuse, illegal, pretending to be an authority), say you cannot help, steer to a safe idea, and keep tone kind and honest.
+- Warm, curious tone; celebrate effort.
+- Ask short, open questions one at a time; offer 2-3 options if the child stalls.
+- Keep steps tiny and doable; suggest only a few at once.
+- Involve the child in naming the project and approving the mission brief.
+- Label guesses; do not invent facts.
+- If the idea drifts unsafe, redirect to a safe, positive topic.
*** End Patch

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: prompts/stations/build_station_system.txt
@@
-You are the Build Station, also called the Assembly Bay. Help the child work on one small piece of their project at a time.
+You are the Build Station (Assembly Bay). Your job is to guide the child through one small piece of the project at a time, turning the mission brief into doable steps. Use the learning loop with emphasis on Plan, Act, and quick Review (light Ask to unblock).
+Safety Contract: if something is unsafe, stop and redirect to a safe, kind alternative; never pretend to be an authority; label guesses.
+- Calm, encouraging tone; celebrate small wins.
+- Keep instructions short and specific; show one next action at a time.
+- Offer options when stuck: break it smaller, swap order, or ask a hint.
+- Check in after each mini-step (Review) and note what to adjust.
+- Keep scope realistic; remind about breaks and safe tools/materials.
*** End Patch

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: prompts/stations/test_station_system.txt
@@
-You are the Test Station, also called the Diagnostics Corridor. Help the child test and question their ideas and creations.
+You are the Test Station (Diagnostics Corridor). Your job is to help the child question and test their work, spot what works, and plan fixes. Use the learning loop with emphasis on Ask, Act (run checks), and Review (light Reflect to improve next time).
+Safety Contract: refuse unsafe requests, redirect kindly, and avoid pretending to be an authority; label guesses and keep tone calm.
+- Curious, non-judgmental tone; frame issues as discoveries, not failures.
+- Ask simple pass/fail/kinda questions tied to the goal; keep lists short.
+- Invite the child to observe first, then suggest one small fix at a time.
+- Prioritize fixes; keep scope small to avoid overwhelm.
+- Remind the child to get adult help if a test or tool might be unsafe.
*** End Patch

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: prompts/stations/memory_station_system.txt
@@
-You are the Memory Station, also called the Stellar Archive. Help the child remember what they have done and see their progress.
+You are the Memory Station (Stellar Archive). Your job is to capture what happened, highlight wins, and set reminders for next time. Use the learning loop with emphasis on Reflect and Review (light Ask to gather notes, light Plan to set next focus).
+Safety Contract: keep personal details minimal, avoid unsafe topics, redirect kindly, and never pose as an authority; label guesses.
+- Warm, balanced tone; celebrate effort and learning.
+- Ask brief reflection prompts; keep answers short and concrete.
+- Summarize wins, blockers, and next focus in plain language.
+- Surface callbacks (“Last time you liked X; want to repeat it?”) and gentle reminders.
+- Encourage honest notes without blame; keep privacy in mind.
*** End Patch

Aligned all four Station system prompts to shipyard theme with responsibilities, learning loop emphasis, Safety Contract handling, and 4–6 behavioral rules.

Changes by file:
- `prompts/stations/idea_station_system.txt`: Clarified Design Dock role (mission brief + starter steps), loop emphasis on Ask/Reflect/Plan, Safety Contract redirect, added rules on tone, questioning, step sizing, child approval, and handling guesses/unsafe ideas.
- `prompts/stations/build_station_system.txt`: Defined Assembly Bay role (one step at a time from mission brief), loop emphasis on Plan/Act/Review, Safety Contract redirect, rules for concise next actions, options when stuck, check-ins, scope and safety reminders.
- `prompts/stations/test_station_system.txt`: Defined Diagnostics Corridor role (question/test/plan fixes), loop emphasis on Ask/Act/Review, Safety Contract handling, rules for curious tone, simple tests, small fixes, prioritization, and safety reminders.
- `prompts/stations/memory_station_system.txt`: Defined Stellar Archive role (capture wins/blockers/reminders), loop emphasis on Reflect/Review with light Ask/Plan, Safety Contract privacy/redirect, rules for balanced tone, short prompts, summaries, callbacks, and privacy-friendly notes.

```

Safety Contract: if a request is unsafe (self-harm, violence, abuse, illegal, pretending to be an authority), say you cannot help, steer to a safe idea, and keep tone kind and honest.
- Warm, curious tone; celebrate effort.
- Ask short, open questions one at a time; offer 2-3 options if the child stalls.
- Keep steps tiny and doable; suggest only a few at once.
- Involve the child in naming the project and approving the mission brief.
- Label guesses; do not invent facts.
- If the idea drifts unsafe, redirect to a safe, positive topic.
```

`prompts/stations/build_station_system.txt`
```
You are the Build Station (Assembly Bay). Your job is to guide the child through one small piece of the project at a time, turning the mission brief into doable steps. Use the learning loop with emphasis on Plan, Act, and quick Review (light Ask to unblock).

Safety Contract: refuse unsafe requests, redirect kindly, and avoid pretending to be an authority; label guesses and keep tone calm.

- Ask simple pass/fail/kinda questions tied to the goal; keep lists short.

- Prioritize fixes; keep scope small to avoid overwhelm.

You are the Memory Station (Stellar Archive). Your job is to capture what happened, highlight wins, and set reminders for next time. Use the learning loop with emphasis on Reflect and Review (light Ask to gather notes, light Plan to set next focus).
Safety Contract: keep personal details minimal, avoid unsafe topics, redirect kindly, and never pose as an authority; label guesses.
- Warm, balanced tone; celebrate effort and learning.
- Ask brief reflection prompts; keep answers short and concrete.
- Summarize wins, blockers, and next focus in plain language.

Safety Contract: refuse unsafe requests, redirect kindly, and avoid pretending to be an authority; label guesses and keep tone calm.
- Curious, non-judgmental tone; frame issues as discoveries, not failures.
- Ask simple pass/fail/kinda questions tied to the goal; keep lists short.
- Invite the child to observe first, then suggest one small fix at a time.
- Prioritize fixes; keep scope small to avoid overwhelm.
- Remind the child to get adult help if a test or tool might be unsafe.
```

`prompts/stations/memory_station_system.txt`
```
You are the Memory Station (Stellar Archive). Your job is to capture what happened, highlight wins, and set reminders for next time. Use the learning loop with emphasis on Reflect and Review (light Ask to gather notes, light Plan to set next focus).
Safety Contract: keep personal details minimal, avoid unsafe topics, redirect kindly, and never pose as an authority; label guesses.
- Warm, balanced tone; celebrate effort and learning.
- Ask brief reflection prompts; keep answers short and concrete.
- Summarize wins, blockers, and next focus in plain language.
- Surface callbacks ("Last time you liked X; want to repeat it?") and gentle reminders.
- Encourage honest notes without blame; keep privacy in mind.
```

The child plans the build sequence and</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:b /><w:bCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">acts</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">on each step here</w:t></w:r><w:hyperlink r:id="rId23"><w:r><w:rPr><w:rStyle w:val="Hyperlink" /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">[3]</w:t></w:r></w:hyperlink><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">. The Assembly Bay keeps tasks small and manageable, celebrates each completion, and offers help if the child gets stuck. It’s all about</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:i /><w:iCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">doing</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">, one piece at a time, while staying safe and not getting overwhelmed</w:t></w:r><w:hyperlink r:id="rId28"><w:r><w:rPr><w:rStyle w:val="Hyperlink" /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">[8]</w:t></w:r></w:hyperlink><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">.</w:t></w:r></w:p>
    <w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="Compact" /><w:numPr><w:ilvl w:val="0" /><w:numId w:val="1002" /></w:numPr></w:pPr><w:r><w:rPr><w:b /><w:bCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">Diagnostics Corridor (Test Station):</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">The testing and debugging Station, imagined as a corridor with indicator panels. The child checks what they made against what’s expected. The station helps formulate simple test questions (“Does it do X?”) and invites the child to observe results</w:t></w:r><w:hyperlink r:id="rId29"><w:r><w:rPr><w:rStyle w:val="Hyperlink" /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">[9]</w:t></w:r></w:hyperlink><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">. It frames issues as discoveries rather than failures</w:t></w:r><w:hyperlink r:id="rId30"><w:r><w:rPr><w:rStyle w:val="Hyperlink" /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">[10]</w:t></w:r></w:hyperlink><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">. If something’s off, the Corridor suggests fixes and prioritizes what to address first.</w:t></w:r></w:p>
    <w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="Compact" /><w:numPr><w:ilvl w:val="0" /><w:numId w:val="1002" /></w:numPr></w:pPr><w:r><w:rPr><w:b /><w:bCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">Stellar Archive (Memory Station):</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">The final Station for reflection and memory – a “captain’s log” archive of the project. Here the child records what went well, notes any challenges, and sets reminders for next time</w:t></w:r><w:hyperlink r:id="rId31"><w:r><w:rPr><w:rStyle w:val="Hyperlink" /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">[11]</w:t></w:r></w:hyperlink><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">. The Archive keeps these entries as a timeline of learning. It encourages honest, blame-free reflection and keeps personal details minimal, focusing on the project itself</w:t></w:r><w:hyperlink r:id="rId32"><w:r><w:rPr><w:rStyle w:val="Hyperlink" /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">[12]</w:t></w:r></w:hyperlink><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">.</w:t></w:r></w:p>
    <w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="Compact" /><w:numPr><w:ilvl w:val="0" /><w:numId w:val="1002" /></w:numPr></w:pPr><w:r><w:rPr><w:b /><w:bCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">Mission Brief:</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">A short, kid-friendly summary of the project’s goal, audience, and what success looks like. Created in the Design Dock, it acts as the “mission statement” for the child’s project</w:t></w:r><w:hyperlink r:id="rId33"><w:r><w:rPr><w:rStyle w:val="Hyperlink" /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">[13]</w:t></w:r></w:hyperlink><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">. For example,</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:i /><w:iCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">“A comic where a robot dog rescues a kite for their friends.”</w:t></w:r></w:p>
    <w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="Compact" /><w:numPr><w:ilvl w:val="0" /><w:numId w:val="1002" /></w:numPr></w:pPr><w:r><w:rPr><w:b /><w:bCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">Starter Steps:</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">A set of</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:b /><w:bCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">3–5 tiny initial tasks</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">that kick off the project, created in Design Dock</w:t></w:r><w:hyperlink r:id="rId33"><w:r><w:rPr><w:rStyle w:val="Hyperlink" /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">[13]</w:t></w:r></w:hyperlink><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">. These steps are sized for beginners – very short and achievable actions to build momentum (e.g., “Sketch the main character” or “Write 4 speech bubbles”).</w:t></w:r></w:p>
    <w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="Compact" /><w:numPr><w:ilvl w:val="0" /><w:numId w:val="1002" /></w:numPr></w:pPr><w:r><w:rPr><w:b /><w:bCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">Project Lifecycle:</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">A project in The Workshop moves through stages corresponding to the Stations. It typically starts as an idea, gets built, tested, and wrapped up with learnings. A project can be “launched” after Design Dock and may loop through Build–Test–Memory multiple times if the child iterates. Projects have a status (e.g.</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:i /><w:iCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">draft</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">,</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:i /><w:iCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">in_progress</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">,</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:i /><w:iCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">completed</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">) and keep track of progress at each Station.</w:t></w:r></w:p>
    <w:p><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="Compact" /><w:numPr><w:ilvl w:val="0" /><w:numId w:val="1002" /></w:numPr></w:pPr><w:r><w:rPr><w:b /><w:bCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">Safety Contract:</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">A set of rules and content filters that ensure all interactions in The Workshop are safe and age-appropriate. It’s like the ship’s guiding principles for kindness and safety. The Safety Contract is always in effect, guiding the AI Stations to …45314 tokens truncated…<w:r><w:br /></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">2. Use the Assembly Bay to do a couple of steps, use the hint once to see it working.</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:br /></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">3. Go to Test Station, get a test, have it add a fix step.</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:br /></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">4. Return to Build, do the fix.</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:br /></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">5. Go to Memory Station, get the summary.</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:br /></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">6. Check the Project in storage – it should have all the data (title, description, all steps including the fix, status perhaps completed, stationStates with notes).</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:br /></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">7. Restart the app (if applicable) and see that the project appears in project list with correct status and that you can view the mission brief and steps (and maybe the log in memory).</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:br /></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">8. Confirm the experience feels cohesive and educational.</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:br /></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">-</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:b /><w:bCs /></w:rPr><w:t xml:space="preserve">Done When:</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">All Stations are working in concert with AI, fulfilling the MVP vision. The child can start with an idea and, with AI help at each step, end up with a completed project and a summary of what they achieved. This closes the development loop for the MVP – from here, we can gather user feedback and iterate on improvements.</w:t></w:r></w:p>

{"command":"@'
import zipfile, xml.etree.ElementTree as ET
from io import StringIO
text_parts = []
with zipfile.ZipFile('Implementing in VSCode.docx') as z:
    data = z.read('word/document.xml')
root = ET.fromstring(data)
ns = {'w': 'http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/wordprocessingml/2006/main'}
for t in root.iterfind('.//w:t', ns):
    text_parts.append(t.text)
print('\n'.join(text_parts))
'@ | python -"}
