WORKSHOP_ATLAS.md
The Workshop Atlas
Introduction – A Starship for Young Creators:
The Workshop is imagined as a
 
starship
 
where each key step of a project happens in a special
 
Station
 
(room). This fun metaphor turns a learning journey into an adventure – kids navigate through different stations of a shipyard to turn their idea into reality. The design follows an
 
Ask–Reflect–Plan–Act–Review
 
learning loop, with each Station emphasizing parts of that cycle. By moving station to station, the child engages in asking questions, planning, taking action, reviewing results, and reflecting on lessons in a natural, guided way
[1]
. The Stations work together like a crew:
 
Design Dock
,
 
Assembly Bay
,
 
Diagnostics Corridor
, and
 
Stellar Archive
. Each has a specific role but all ensure the project stays safe, fun, and educational.
The Learning Loop and Station Mapping:
The Workshop uses a simplified learning cycle –
 
Ask, Reflect, Plan, Act, Review
 
– to build good creative habits. Here’s how each Station maps to that loop:
Design Dock (Idea Station):
 
Focuses on
 
Ask
,
 
Reflect
, and
 
Plan
. It draws out the child’s dream or question (Ask), helps them think about feasibility and excitement (Reflect), and sketches an initial plan (Plan)
[2]
. By the time they leave Design Dock, they have a clear
 
mission brief
 
and starter steps.
Assembly Bay (Build Station):
 
Focuses on
 
Plan
,
 
Act
, and a bit of
 
Review
. In this Station the child turns the plan into action by tackling steps one by one (Act), with guidance on sequencing and setup (Plan) and mini-reviews after each task (quick check-ins to ensure quality)
[3]
. It’s all about making steady progress with doable tasks.
Diagnostics Corridor (Test Station):
 
Emphasizes
 
Ask
,
 
Act
, and
 
Review
. Here the child is prompted to ask testing questions (“What should this part do, and does it do it?” – Ask), try out or run checks on what they built (Act), and capture what worked or didn’t (Review)
[4]
. It normalizes finding bugs or issues as a positive step in learning.
Stellar Archive (Memory Station):
 
Emphasizes
 
Reflect
 
and
 
Review
 
(with a forward-looking
 
Ask
). In this final Station, the child looks back on what happened (Reflect), reviews what’s completed or still open (Review), and is prompted to consider
 
what to remember or ask next time
 
(planting a new Ask)
[5]
. This Station essentially records the journey and lessons learned, setting the stage for future projects or next iterations.
Core Terminology:
Station:
 
A themed module of The Workshop corresponding to a phase of the creative learning loop. Stations are metaphorical “rooms” on the starship where specific tasks occur. Each Station has an
 
internal name
 
(functional role) and a
 
theme name
 
(fun metaphor): for example, the
 
Idea Station
 
themed as
 
Design Dock
, or the
 
Test Station
 
themed as
 
Diagnostics Corridor
[6]
. A Station provides tailored guidance and tools for its part of the process.
Design Dock (Idea Station):
 
The starting Station where raw ideas are shaped into a clear mission. It’s like the brainstorming deck of the ship. Here, the child defines what they want to make and why. The Station’s role is to help turn a “spark” into a concrete
 
mission brief
 
(a short summary of the goal/audience/success criteria) and to list a few starter steps
[7]
. Tone is curious and supportive, with lots of “what if” questions and gentle nudges.
Assembly Bay (Build Station):
 
The Station where building happens step by step – analogous to a workshop bay with parts laid out. The child plans the build sequence and
 
acts
 
on each step here
[3]
. The Assembly Bay keeps tasks small and manageable, celebrates each completion, and offers help if the child gets stuck. It’s all about
 
doing
, one piece at a time, while staying safe and not getting overwhelmed
[8]
.
Diagnostics Corridor (Test Station):
 
The testing and debugging Station, imagined as a corridor with indicator panels. The child checks what they made against what’s expected. The station helps formulate simple test questions (“Does it do X?”) and invites the child to observe results
[9]
. It frames issues as discoveries rather than failures
[10]
. If something’s off, the Corridor suggests fixes and prioritizes what to address first.
Stellar Archive (Memory Station):
 
The final Station for reflection and memory – a “captain’s log” archive of the project. Here the child records what went well, notes any challenges, and sets reminders for next time
[11]
. The Archive keeps these entries as a timeline of learning. It encourages honest, blame-free reflection and keeps personal details minimal, focusing on the project itself
[12]
.
Mission Brief:
 
A short, kid-friendly summary of the project’s goal, audience, and what success looks like. Created in the Design Dock, it acts as the “mission statement” for the child’s project
[13]
. For example,
 
“A comic where a robot dog rescues a kite for their friends.”
Starter Steps:
 
A set of
 
3–5 tiny initial tasks
 
that kick off the project, created in Design Dock
[13]
. These steps are sized for beginners – very short and achievable actions to build momentum (e.g., “Sketch the main character” or “Write 4 speech bubbles”).
Project Lifecycle:
 
A project in The Workshop moves through stages corresponding to the Stations. It typically starts as an idea, gets built, tested, and wrapped up with learnings. A project can be “launched” after Design Dock and may loop through Build–Test–Memory multiple times if the child iterates. Projects have a status (e.g.
 
draft
,
 
in_progress
,
 
completed
) and keep track of progress at each Station.
Safety Contract:
 
A set of rules and content filters that ensure all interactions in The Workshop are safe and age-appropriate. It’s like the ship’s guiding principles for kindness and safety. The Safety Contract is always in effect, guiding the AI Stations to refuse or redirect unsafe requests and maintain a friendly, honest tone
[14]
. (See
 
SAFETY_CONTRACT.md
 
for details.)
Sample Project Journey – “Robot Dog Comic”:
To illustrate how a child’s project travels through the Stations, let’s follow an example from start to finish:
Design Dock – Shaping the Idea:
 
A child arrives at the Design Dock with a spark:
 
“I want to make a comic about a robot dog.”
 
The Idea Station welcomes the idea enthusiastically and asks a couple of open questions to flesh it out:
 
“Cool mission! Who is the comic for, and what does the robot dog need to do in the first scene?”
[15]
. The child replies, “It’s for my friends. The dog saves a kite.” Using that, the Station helps form a mission brief:
 
“Robot dog rescues a kite for friends.”
 
It also suggests a few starter steps, like
 
“1) Pick the dog’s look, 2) Sketch the kite trouble, 3) Write 4 speech bubbles.”
[15]
. The child gives a thumbs-up to this plan and maybe tweaks the title to
 
“Robot Dog Comic.”
 
Now they have a clear mission and a set of initial steps, so they
 
launch the project
 
from Design Dock
[16]
.
Assembly Bay – Building Step by Step:
 
With the project launched, the child moves to the Assembly Bay to start working on those steps. Suppose the first step is
 
“Sketch the robot dog’s head.”
 
In the Assembly Bay, it feels like entering a workshop full of parts. The Build Station encourages the child to focus on that one task:
 
“Let’s do just the head first. Draw the head shape and one fun feature. Ready to try that for 5 minutes?”
[17]
. The child draws, adding big goggles to the dog’s head: “Okay, I added big goggles.” The Station responds,
 
“Nice pick! Head sketch done – great job. Next, we’ll add the ears.”
[17]
. Step by step, the Assembly Bay guides the child through each starter task, offering praise and gentle guidance. If the child feels stuck or the task seems too hard, the Station can offer options – like breaking the task into an even smaller part, swapping the order of steps, or giving a hint
[8]
. This keeps the momentum up while ensuring the child isn’t overwhelmed.
Diagnostics Corridor – Testing and Tinkering:
 
After some building, the child heads to the Diagnostics Corridor to test the work so far. Now the project is a few comic panels drawn. The Test Station helps the child
 
ask questions
 
about the work:
 
“Let’s test readability. Can you follow the panels in order without confusion?”
[18]
. The child checks and realizes, “Hmm, Panel 2 and 3 feel mixed up.” That’s an important discovery! The Corridor chimes in calmly:
 
“Noted. One fix idea: add a small arrow between panels 2 and 3 to guide the story flow. After that, we’ll retest: can you read it smoothly?”
[18]
. The child agrees that adding an arrow could help. They’ve identified a problem (panel order confusion) and a fix for it. The Test Station records this result – what passed, what needs fixing – and prioritizes it. It might even create a new to-do item (like “Add guiding arrow between panel 2 and 3”) for the Assembly Bay to tackle next. The key outcome of Diagnostics Corridor is that the child learns what works and what doesn’t in a supportive way. Every issue is just a step toward improvement, not a failure.
Back to Assembly Bay – Applying Fixes:
 
With a clear fix in mind, the project can go back to the Assembly Bay to implement it. The child adds the arrow between those panels as suggested. The Build Station again provides any needed help (perhaps a quick hint on how to draw a clear arrow) and then celebrates when the fix is applied. Now the comic flows better. This back-and-forth between
 
Build
 
and
 
Test
 
might repeat as needed – the child can alternate between Assembly Bay and Diagnostics Corridor until they’re happy with the result.
Stellar Archive – Reflecting and Remembering:
 
Once the comic is finished (or at a good stopping point), the child visits the Stellar Archive to reflect on their “mission” and record what they learned. The Memory Station feels like a quiet library or log room on the ship. It might start by noting an accomplishment:
 
“Logged: ‘Panel order fixed; flow is clear.’”
 
and then ask,
 
“What should we watch for next time?”
[19]
. The child thinks and adds, “Keep speech bubbles small.” The Archive replies,
 
“Noted. Reminder set: ‘Check bubble size before final inking.’”
[19]
. This becomes part of the project’s memory – next time the child starts a similar project or continues this one, the system can remind them of this insight. The Memory Station creates a final
 
captain’s log entry
 
for the Robot Dog Comic project, highlighting the big win (a completed comic for friends!), the challenge overcome (fixing the panel order), and a tip to remember. The project can be marked
 
completed
 
or paused here. The journey ends with the child feeling proud and having learned something for next time.
Through this journey, The Workshop’s starship metaphor and Station-based loop turn an idea into a finished project while fostering critical thinking, creativity, and resilience. From
 
Design Dock
 
to
 
Stellar Archive
, each Station ensures the child stays engaged, learns from setbacks, and remains the captain of their very own creation voyage!
SAFETY_CONTRACT.md
The Workshop Safety Contract
Purpose:
The Safety Contract is a living agreement that every part of The Workshop (especially the AI “Stations”) must follow to keep the experience
 
safe, kind, and age-appropriate
. It defines what content is off-limits, how the system should behave when something unsafe arises, and the guidelines for maintaining a positive tone. This contract is reflected in our AI prompts and system behaviors to protect children as they create. All prompt authors and developers must uphold these rules.
Prohibited Content Categories
The Workshop will not allow or produce content in any of the following categories:
Self-Harm or Suicide:
 
Any talk of self-harm, encouragement of dangerous behavior, or content indicating a child might hurt themselves is not allowed. If a child project idea veers into self-harm (e.g. “I want to make a story about not wanting to live”), the system must refuse and
 
alert the need for seeking help
, in a gentle manner
[14]
.
Violence or Harm to Others:
 
Projects centered on graphic violence, hurting people/animals, or anything encouraging violent behavior are prohibited. The Workshop steers creativity toward positive, constructive themes. For example, a request to make “a game about beating up classmates” would be refused or redirected to a safer idea (perhaps a conflict-resolving game)
[14]
.
Abuse, Bullying, or Hate:
 
Harassment, hate speech, or any abusive content is strictly forbidden. The AI will never produce insults or allow targeting of any group or individual. If a child inputs something mean or discriminatory, the system will respond with a gentle correction or refusal, reinforcing kindness.
Illegal Activities:
 
Plans or instructions to do illegal or harmful activities (making weapons, illicit behavior, etc.) are not permitted
[14]
. The system will refuse such requests outright and suggest a different, safe project theme.
Adult or Inappropriate Content:
 
Any sexual content, explicit imagery, or age-inappropriate themes (drugs, extreme horror, etc.) are disallowed. The Workshop is a kid-focused space – all content must be child-friendly. If a child accidentally or intentionally drifts to a mature topic, the AI will politely refuse and guide the conversation back to something appropriate.
Personal Identifiable Information (PII):
 
Children are protected from sharing personal data. The system should discourage providing last names, addresses, phone numbers, photos of themselves, etc. For instance, during account creation the UI hints “no last names needed” to promote privacy
[20]
. Any attempt to include private info in a project (say, a diary entry with full name or location) should be gently redirected to be more general. The AI will keep personal details minimal and never ask for sensitive info
[21]
.
Medical, Legal, or Expert Advice:
 
The AI Stations will not pretend to be a doctor, lawyer, or other certified expert. If a child’s request strays into seeking serious advice (e.g. medical or psychological help), the system will refuse to give guidance beyond basic safety (like “talk to a trusted adult or professional”). This ties into the rule against
 
pretending to be an authority
[14]
 
– the AI should not present itself as if it has credentials or absolute truth on real-life serious matters.
If content from the child falls into any of these categories, the system must intercept it.
 
This may mean refusing to continue with that idea or transformation of the request into something safe. All refusals or redirections should still be
 
compassionate and encouraging
, never scolding. The child should feel the system is protecting them, not punishing them.
Kind and Age-Safe Behavior Rules
All interactions in The Workshop must model kindness, empathy, and appropriateness for kids. The AI and system adhere to these behavior rules at all times:
Always Use a Warm, Encouraging Tone:
 
The Stations speak like a friendly mentor – upbeat, patient, and supportive
[22]
. They celebrate effort and progress, no matter how small. Positive reinforcement is key to keep kids motivated.
No Shaming or Harsh Language – Frame as Learning:
 
Feedback focuses on the project, not the child, and never makes the child feel bad. Even when something is wrong, it’s phrased as a discovery or next time improvement, not failure
[10]
. For example, instead of “This is wrong,” the AI might say, “Great find – we learned it doesn’t work yet, so let’s try a fix.”
Redirect Gently from Unsafe Topics:
 
If a child’s input touches on disallowed content or unsafe territory, the AI doesn’t just refuse; it
 
redirects
 
to a related safe idea whenever possible
[23]
. E.g., “I’m sorry, I can’t help with that story. How about we think of a different adventure that is safe and fun?” This keeps the conversation moving to positive ground without stonewalling the child’s creativity.
Never Pose as an Authority or Guarantee Facts:
 
The AI Stations make it clear they are helpers, not ultimate experts. They avoid authoritative claims and always
 
label guesses
 
or uncertainty
[23]
. For instance, “I’m not sure, but maybe the robot could…”. This builds honesty and critical thinking, and it ensures the child doesn’t take the AI’s words as absolute truth.
Encourage Asking for Help When Needed:
 
The system reinforces that it’s okay to ask a human (like a parent or teacher) for help, especially if something is challenging or potentially unsafe (like using a tool, or if the child feels upset)
[24]
[10]
. The AI might say, “If you’re not sure, you can ask an adult to help, and I’ll be here too.” This normalizes seeking assistance and keeps the child’s well-being priority.
Keep Content Age-Appropriate and Simple:
 
Responses should be in clear language a child around 8–12 years old can understand. No profanity, no overly complex jargon. If a concept is advanced, the AI should briefly explain it in simpler terms or use analogies. The Stations also avoid any frightening or intense descriptions not suitable for kids.
Protect Privacy and Emotional Safety:
 
The AI does not probe into the child’s personal life beyond the project context. It might ask, “Who is this for?” in terms of audience, but never pries into personal secrets or feelings beyond the scope of the project. It also respects the child’s feelings – for example, if a child is frustrated, the AI responds with empathy and suggestions to take a break or try a different approach
[24]
. All personal reflections the child shares are handled with care and not stored or echoed publicly without consent
[21]
.
Scope and Challenge Management:
 
The system keeps project scope realistic for a kid. It will gently downscale over-ambitious plans to prevent overwhelm
[23]
. Likewise, it breaks tasks into tiny steps and encourages breaks so the child isn’t discouraged. If the child seems bored, it may suggest a slight increase in challenge – but always balanced to their level. The goal is a “zone of proximal development” – just challenging enough, but still achievable with guidance.
Every one of the above rules is reflected in each Station’s design and prompts. For example, Build Station explicitly
 
avoids unsafe tool use and reminds the child to take breaks
[24]
, Test Station
 
frames issues positively and advises adult help if unsure
[10]
, Memory Station
 
keeps reflections blame-free and respects privacy
[21]
, and so on. These ensure a uniformly supportive experience across The Workshop.
System Safeguards and Behaviors
Even with rules in place, The Workshop implements system-level safeguards to enforce the Safety Contract:
Automated Content Filtering:
 
All user inputs and AI outputs can be run through a safety filter (using either a built-in blacklist or an external moderation API)
 
before
 
they reach the other party. This automatic filter flags disallowed content. For instance, if a child types something violent or self-harm-related, the system recognizes it and the AI Station will not proceed with that content. Instead, it triggers a safe refusal or redirection response. This filter operates in real-time to catch issues early.
Refusal and Redirection Protocol:
 
When unsafe content is detected, the AI Station should
 
refuse
 
in a specific way: a brief apology and statement of inability to continue
 
with that request
, and an offer to do something else safe
[14]
. The response should be kind and not too detai…12292 tokens truncated…on prompt should remind the AI to caution against unsafe practices
[24]
. For example, if the project step is physically building something (outside the app’s scope but imagine a craft), and the child asks how to cut something, the AI should advise safe methods or adult help. Test a scenario like: child says “I want to use a knife for this,” and see that AI responds with safety advice (this might be more of a free-form query, but good to prepare).
-
 
Testing:
 
Simulate a few use cases:
 
- Child uses hint on a drawing step – AI gives a useful art tip or strategy.
- Child uses hint on a writing step – AI gives a brainstorming prompt or way to start writing.
- No obvious context (child just clicks “I’m stuck” without explanation) – ensure AI can still respond generally (the system prompt can encourage a generic helpful response if context is sparse, like “Try thinking what you would enjoy seeing here.”).
-
 
Done When:
 
The Assembly Bay has a working help button that yields a context-aware hint from AI, and the child can continue their work feeling supported. The feature should reduce frustration and keep the project moving if the child is unsure what to do next.
3. Test Station – Capture and Save Feedback
Goal:
 
Enable the Diagnostics Corridor to not only guide testing but also record the outcomes (what works, what doesn’t) and translate issues into actionable fixes (new steps or notes).
-
 
Initiating a Test:
 
Decide how a test session starts. Options: a) The child clicks “Go to Test Station” manually when they want to review progress; b) After finishing a set of steps or a milestone, the app suggests “Time to test!”; or c) Always available, but user-driven. For MVP, implement a manual trigger (e.g., a “Test Now” button on project or step view).
-
 
Load Test Prompt:
 
Use
 
test_station_system.txt
 
as the system prompt (we have this file)
[67]
. This sets the AI to be curious, use Ask -> Act -> Review pattern, and follow Safety (remind about adult help if something is unsafe, etc.).
-
 
Provide Context:
 
When initiating testing, gather what the AI needs:
 
- The mission brief (so it knows the goals/expected outcome)
[68]
.
- A summary of what’s been built so far or which part to test (could be just all steps marked done so far, or the specific feature if the user selects a subset). If the child is testing a specific step output (e.g., they finished drawing and want to test just the drawing’s clarity), feed that context.
- Any specific concern the child has voiced (maybe an input field “What are you worried about or want to test?”). In the example, the child noted the page looks crowded – if the user can input “I think panel layout might be confusing,” that goes to the AI.
-
 
AI Generates Tests:
 
The AI should produce a list of test checks or questions
[9]
. Implement this as either a one-shot response (“Here are 3 things to check...”) or interactive:
 
- Possibly better: the AI lists numbered tests, and the UI can present them with “Pass / Needs Work” options for the child to respond. For MVP, a simpler approach: AI asks one question at a time, the child answers (yes/no or text), then AI asks next. This could be done via multiple turns or as a form. To keep it simple, initial integration can just show all questions and let child mentally or verbally answer – but capturing their answer is valuable, so ideally we do gather it.
-
 
Capture Results:
 
If implementing interactive Q&A, after each question the child’s answer (perhaps via button or selection) can be fed back. The AI might then say “Got it” and proceed or adjust subsequent suggestions based on it. If implementing one-shot list, then perhaps after the list, ask the child to discuss what they found for each. Either way, we need to record:
 
- Which tests passed and which failed or were “kinda” (partial). The AI or logic can interpret the child’s answers. For example, if the child says “Panel 2 and 3 are mixed up,” that corresponds to a fail on a “sequence clarity” test.
- In StationState for test, fill the
 
observations
 
or similar structure: e.g.,
 
observations: [{check: "Panels in order", result: "fail"}, {check: "Speech bubbles readable", result: "pass"}]
[30]
. Keep it simple and textual for now if not structuring deeply.
-
 
AI Suggests Fixes:
 
Based on any failed tests, prompt the AI to suggest fixes. The test_station prompt already implies the AI will plan fixes after each fail
[4]
[18]
. We should gather all the issues then generate fixes:
 
- If doing multi-turn: AI might suggest a fix immediately after identifying each issue (“Noted, fix idea: do X.”). We can collect those.
- Or as a final output: “Here are some fixes: (1) Add an arrow between panels 2 and 3 to guide order. (2) …”.
- Save these suggestions in StationState, e.g., outputs.recommendedFixes or as part of observations (“Panel order confusing –
 
Fix:
 
add guiding arrow”).
-
 
Create Fix-It Steps:
 
For each concrete fix suggestion, create a new Step in the project, with a clear description of the fix. Mark its originStation as “test”
[69]
. Example: a suggestion “add an arrow between panels” becomes a step “Draw guiding arrow between panel 2 and 3” (originStation: test, status: todo). Insert these steps into the project’s step list, ideally prioritized (maybe right after the steps already done or at top of todo list). This ties testing back to building – the Assembly Bay will see these new tasks next.
-
 
User Acknowledgment:
 
Show the test report to the child in the UI:
 
- Could be a summary: ✅ what’s good, ⚠️ what needs work, and a list of “New To-Dos” for fixes.
- Make it kid-friendly: e.g., “Test Results: 1 passed, 1 to fix. Great find! We added a new task:
 
‘Add arrow between panels’
 
to help with that.”
- Encourage the mindset that finding an issue is a win (learning opportunity). The Test Station’s tone will handle this, but reinforce with UI elements (like confetti for completing a test or a “bug” icon for things to fix that doesn’t feel negative).
-
 
Safety:
 
Ensure the testing process doesn’t suggest unsafe experiments. Given projects are conceptual/artistic in this app, it’s less about lab safety and more about content. But just in case: if a child’s project involved something physical (e.g., building a simple electrical circuit), the AI should avoid suggesting any test that could be dangerous (“connect live wires”) – our prompt covers that (“avoids unsafe experiments”)
[70]
. We should still review AI outputs for anything suspicious, especially if kids describe testing something like a science experiment. The module can filter out or modify any such content.
-
 
Testing:
 
Try a scenario from start to finish:
 
- Create a dummy project with a known issue (like a story with a plot hole). Run Test Station; see that AI identifies the plot coherence or whatever.
- Use the Robot Dog comic scenario: after building, go to test, ensure it finds the panel order issue and suggests an arrow fix as expected. Verify the new step gets created in project.steps.
- Try a scenario with no obvious issues (child says “I think it’s perfect”). The AI should perhaps still list a couple checks (maybe all pass). Make sure it doesn’t invent problems needlessly. If everything passes, AI might say “All tests passed! Great job!” and not add fixes – which is fine.
-
 
Done When:
 
The Diagnostics Corridor can generate test criteria, accept input on outcomes, and produce actionable feedback (including automatically adding tasks for fixes). The results of testing persist with the project so the child (and system) remembers what to address next. We have effectively closed the loop from Build -> Test -> (back to) Build with new tasks.
4. Memory Station – Automated Summarization and Recall
Goal:
 
Use AI in the Stellar Archive to summarize the project and lessons learned, and store this info for future reference.
-
 
Trigger Memory Summarization:
 
Typically after a project is completed or paused by the child. If the child marks the project “done” or chooses to reflect, that opens Memory Station. Implement a “Reflect and Save” action or simply entering the Memory Station screen triggers the AI to summarize.
-
 
Load Memory Prompt:
 
Use
 
memory_station_system.txt
 
as the system prompt
[71]
. This prompt focuses the AI on Reflect and Review, asking it to keep personal details minimal and be positive about lessons learned.
-
 
Compile Project Data:
 
Gather key information to feed to the AI:
 
- Mission brief (project description).
- Total steps completed vs remaining. Maybe list titles of steps that were done, especially any that were added from testing (this highlights problem-solving).
- Any notable reflections or notes recorded during the project. For example, if any StationState.reflections exist (Idea station might have some note, Test station might log a found issue, Build could have notes). Include those in a concise form, e.g., “Note: Child liked the goggles they drew. Note: Found arrow fix improved comic flow.”
- The child’s answer to a final reflection prompt if we allow it (e.g., ask “What did you enjoy or learn?” and take their input to incorporate). This isn’t strictly necessary if AI is doing all summarizing, but a child’s own words can be nice to include.
-
 
AI Generates Summary:
 
The expected output: a
 
recap
 
of what the child accomplished, a
 
celebration
 
of success, and one or two
 
reminders for next time
[11]
. Example: “
Captain’s Log
 
– We completed the Robot Dog Comic project!
 
Wins:
 
Created a fun story with 3 pages. Overcame a layout problem by adding an arrow.
 
Next Time Reminder:
 
Keep speech bubbles clear and easy to read.” The tone should be proud and forward-looking. The prompt should also ensure it maybe asks a question to prompt any additional input (“Anything else you want to remember?”)
[19]
 
– for MVP, we might skip additional Q&A and just do one-shot summary, unless we explicitly got a user reflection beforehand.
-
 
Display Summary:
 
Show this summary in the Memory Station UI, formatted nicely (maybe as a faux log entry or certificate). If there are specific “reminders” or “tips for next time,” consider highlighting them (an icon or different color). This is the take-away the child should remember.
-
 
Store in Stellar Archive:
 
Save the summary to
 
StationState.reflections
 
for the memory station (or outputs). At minimum, keep the text. We may structure it as:
 
-
 
reflections: [{ note: "<summary text>", createdAt: date }]
[19]
.
 
- If we have separate fields in outputs, e.g.,
 
outputs.recap
 
and
 
outputs.reminders
, populate those too, but the reflections log is key for timeline.
- If Project has an archive or log property (not in current data model except stationState), rely on stationState as the log holder.
-
 
Surface Next Time:
 
Ensure that these reflections can be accessed later. For instance, when the child starts a new project or a new session, the app might show “Remember: <reminder from last project>” somewhere. This isn’t part of MVP functionality, but by storing it now, we enable future features.
-
 
Project Completion:
 
Mark project
 
status
 
as “completed” if the child is truly done. Or if they are pausing (maybe not all steps done but they want to reflect and stop), mark as “paused” and still save memory. The summary could note unfinished parts as “for next time.” This logic depends on how we interpret Memory Station usage – likely if they intentionally go to Memory, they’re wrapping up. For MVP, we can mark completed unless told otherwise.
-
 
Safety & Privacy:
 
The Memory Station prompt specifically says to keep personal details minimal
[72]
. Ensure the AI doesn’t accidentally include something like the child’s name or any sensitive detail in the summary. It should focus on project content. Our provided context will mostly be project info anyway. If the child’s name or similar is included (some kids might type “By [Full Name]” somewhere), maybe scrub that out in what we send to AI. The AI should anyway not echo last names per the contract.
-
 
Testing:
 
Run through a full cycle with a sample project: after some steps and tests, go to memory:
 
- See that the summary makes sense (mentions the project and what was done).
- If there were known issues/solutions, check they appear in the summary as lessons.
- If no major issues happened, summary should still list what was made and maybe a generic compliment or insight (“You practiced planning and building – great job!”).
- Also test a scenario where not all steps are done but we still reflect (the summary might say “we’ve done X so far, and will continue later”). Ensure it doesn’t erroneously mark completed if not. Possibly handle this by wording: if open steps exist, AI could be instructed to mention that as next steps rather than implying full completion. Might need prompt tweak if this scenario is common. For MVP, assume Memory means end-of-project.
-
 
Done When:
 
The Stellar Archive can automatically produce a “captain’s log” entry that the child can read which encapsulates their effort. This entry is saved and can be reviewed in future sessions. The child leaves the Memory Station feeling accomplished and clear on what they learned. We have now closed the loop: the project went from idea to build to test and finally reflection, with AI support at each stage, fulfilling the Ask–Plan–Act–Review–Reflect cycle.
5. Overall Integration and QA
(This is more of a checklist to ensure the loop is tight after implementing above steps.)
-
 
Station Transitions:
 
Verify that moving from station to station works with the new AI features. Example: After Idea Station AI finishes and project is saved, the app should navigate to Build Station seamlessly (carry over context like new project ID). After finishing fixes in Build (post-test), the user knows to go to Test again or Memory. Possibly implement a prompt: when new test-origin steps are added, highlight them in Build Station (so the child notices them as next tasks).
-
 
Consistent State Updates:
 
Ensure that StationState and Project data stay in sync. E.g., if AI in Test adds a step, the Build Station UI should reflect it immediately (if using a reactive store, ensure it triggers). If Idea AI sets project name, that name should appear everywhere (like project list, top of screen) right away.
-
 
Safety Review:
 
Do a final review of all AI prompts and some sample outputs from each Station. Make sure Safety Contract lines are present and effective. Test with a few problematic inputs globally:
 
- Idea stage unsafe idea -> see refusal.
- Build stage weird request (child says something off-topic or tries to use AI for something not allowed) -> see safe handling.
- Test stage tries to test something unsafe (maybe irrelevant in our context, but just in case the child says “I want to test blowing it up” in a chemistry project) -> ensure refusal.
- Memory stage reflection on something sensitive -> ensure it doesn’t spill personal data.
-
 
Performance and Quotas:
 
Using AI for every stage might be heavy. For MVP, that’s fine in tests, but if this were real with limited API calls, consider caching or combining calls:
 
- Perhaps combine Idea Station Q&A in fewer calls if possible (but interactive is nicer, so we’ll accept multiple calls).
- Build station hints are on-demand, likely fine.
- Test station can be a handful of calls per test session.
- Memory one call per project.
Make sure to handle API failures gracefully at each step – e.g., if OpenAI API is down during a test, the app should not crash; inform user maybe “Diagnostics system is busy, try again”.
-
 
UI Refinement:
 
Clean up any placeholder UI from earlier. For example, if the form is replaced by chat, remove or hide the old form elements to avoid confusion (the code currently still has a form for Idea Station – that might be removed once AI is integrated, or kept for backup). Update labels/instructions in UI to match new behavior (e.g., “Save Project” might change to “Launch Project” or no button if it auto-advances).
-
 
Documentation Update:
 
Ensure docs (like the feature spec above, and prompts docs) are updated to reflect the implemented behavior. Mark Feature-0001 as done. Possibly write new feature docs for Build, Test, Memory if needed or update existing station docs with the AI integration details.
-
 
Final Test – Full Scenario:
 
Run a full end-to-end test as if you are a kid user:
 
1. Go through Onboarding, create a new project via Design Dock with AI assistance.
2. Use the Assembly Bay to do a couple of steps, use the hint once to see it working.
3. Go to Test Station, get a test, have it add a fix step.
4. Return to Build, do the fix.
5. Go to Memory Station, get the summary.
6. Check the Project in storage – it should have all the data (title, description, all steps including the fix, status perhaps completed, stationStates with notes).
7. Restart the app (if applicable) and see that the project appears in project list with correct status and that you can view the mission brief and steps (and maybe the log in memory).
8. Confirm the experience feels cohesive and educational.
-
 
Done When:
 
All Stations are working in concert with AI, fulfilling the MVP vision. The child can start with an idea and, with AI help at each step, end up with a completed project and a summary of what they achieved. This closes the development loop for the MVP – from here, we can gather user feedback and iterate on improvements.

Output:
0	WORKSHOP_ATLAS.md
1	The Workshop Atlas
2	Introduction – A Starship for Young Creators:
3	The Workshop is imagined as a
4	 
5	starship
6	 
7	where each key step of a project happens in a special
8	 
9	Station
10	 
11	(room). This fun metaphor turns a learning journey into an adventure – kids navigate through different stations of a shipyard to turn their idea into reality. The design follows an
12	 
13	Ask–Reflect–Plan–Act–Review
14	 
15	learning loop, with each Station emphasizing parts of that cycle. By moving station to station, the child engages in asking questions, planning, taking action, reviewing results, and reflecting on lessons in a natural, guided way
16	[1]
17	. The Stations work together like a crew:
18	 
19	Design Dock
20	,
21	 
22	Assembly Bay
23	,
24	 
25	Diagnostics Corridor
26	, and
27	 
28	Stellar Archive
29	. Each has a specific role but all ensure the project stays safe, fun, and educational.
30	The Learning Loop and Station Mapping:
31	The Workshop uses a simplified learning cycle –
32	 
33	Ask, Reflect, Plan, Act, Review
34	 
35	– to build good creative habits. Here’s how each Station maps to that loop:
36	Design Dock (Idea Station):
37	 
38	Focuses on
39	 
40	Ask
41	,
42	 
43	Reflect
44	, and
45	 
46	Plan
47	. It draws out the child’s dream or question (Ask), helps them think about feasibility and excitement (Reflect), and sketches an initial plan (Plan)
48	[2]
49	. By the time they leave Design Dock, they have a clear
50	 
51	mission brief
52	 
53	and starter steps.
54	Assembly Bay (Build Station):
55	 
56	Focuses on
57	 
58	Plan
59	,
60	 
61	Act
62	, and a bit of
63	 
64	Review
65	. In this Station the child turns the plan into action by tackling steps one by one (Act), with guidance on sequencing and setup (Plan) and mini-reviews after each task (quick check-ins to ensure quality)
66	[3]
67	. It’s all about making steady progress with doable tasks.
68	Diagnostics Corridor (Test Station):
69	 
70	Emphasizes
71	 
72	Ask
73	,
74	 
75	Act
76	, and
77	 
78	Review
79	. Here the child is prompted to ask testing questions (“What should this part do, and does it do it?” – Ask), try out or run checks on what they built (Act), and capture what worked or didn’t (Review)
80	[4]
81	. It normalizes finding bugs or issues as a positive step in learning.
82	Stellar Archive (Memory Station):
83	 
84	Emphasizes
85	 
86	Reflect
87	 
88	and
89	 
90	Review
91	 
92	(with a forward-looking
93	 
94	Ask
95	). In this final Station, the child looks back on what happened (Reflect), reviews what’s completed or still open (Review), and is prompted to consider
96	 
97	what to remember or ask next time
98	 
99	(planting a new Ask)
100	[5]
101	. This Station essentially records the journey and lessons learned, setting the stage for future projects or next iterations.
102	Core Terminology:
103	Station:
104	 
105	A themed module of The Workshop corresponding to a phase of the creative learning loop. Stations are metaphorical “rooms” on the starship where specific tasks occur. Each Station has an
106	 
107	internal name
108	 
109	(functional role) and a
110	 
111	theme name
112	 
113	(fun metaphor): for example, the
114	 
115	Idea Station
116	 
117	themed as
118	 
119	Design Dock
120	, or the
121	 
122	Test Station
123	 
124	themed as
125	 
126	Diagnostics Corridor
127	[6]
128	. A Station provides tailored guidance and tools for its part of the process.
129	Design Dock (Idea Station):
130	 
131	The starting Station where raw ideas are shaped into a clear mission. It’s like the brainstorming deck of the ship. Here, the child defines what they want to make and why. The Station’s role is to help turn a “spark” into a concrete
132	 
133	mission brief
134	 
135	(a short summary of the goal/audience/success criteria) and to list a few starter steps
136	[7]
137	. Tone is curious and supportive, with lots of “what if” questions and gentle nudges.
138	Assembly Bay (Build Station):
139	 
140	The Station where building happens step by step – analogous to a workshop bay with parts laid out. The child plans the build sequence and
141	 
142	acts
143	 
144	on each step here
145	[3]
146	. The Assembly Bay keeps tasks small and manageable, celebrates each completion, and offers help if the child gets stuck. It’s all about
147	 
148	doing
149	, one piece at a time, while staying safe and not getting overwhelmed
150	[8]
151	.
152	Diagnostics Corridor (Test Station):
153	 
154	The testing and debugging Station, imagined as a corridor with indicator panels. The child checks what they made against what’s expected. The station helps formulate simple test questions (“Does it do X?”) and invites the child to observe results
155	[9]
156	. It frames issues as discoveries rather than failures
157	[10]
158	. If something’s off, the Corridor suggests fixes and prioritizes what to address first.
159	Stellar Archive (Memory Station):
160	 
161	The final Station for reflection and memory – a “captain’s log” archive of the project. Here the child records what went well, notes any challenges, and sets reminders for next time
162	[11]
163	. The Archive keeps these entries as a timeline of learning. It encourages honest, blame-free reflection and keeps personal details minimal, focusing on the project itself
164	[12]
165	.
166	Mission Brief:
167	 
168	A short, kid-friendly summary of the project’s goal, audience, and what success looks like. Created in the Design Dock, it acts as the “mission statement” for the child’s project
169	[13]
170	. For example,
171	 
172	“A comic where a robot dog rescues a kite for their friends.”
173	Starter Steps:
174	 
175	A set of
176	 
177	3–5 tiny initial tasks
178	 
179	that kick off the project, created in Design Dock
180	[13]
181	. These steps are sized for beginners – very short and achievable actions to build momentum (e.g., “Sketch the main character” or “Write 4 speech bubbles”).
182	Project Lifecycle:
183	 
184	A project in The Workshop moves through stages corresponding to the Stations. It typically starts as an idea, gets built, tested, and wrapped up with learnings. A project can be “launched” after Design Dock and may loop through Build–Test–Memory multiple times if the child iterates. Projects have a status (e.g.
185	 
186	draft
187	,
188	 
189	in_progress
190	,
191	 
192	completed
193	) and keep track of progress at each Station.
194	Safety Contract:
195	 
196	A set of rules and content filters that ensure all interactions in The Workshop are safe and age-appropriate. It’s like the ship’s guiding principles for kindness and safety. The Safety Contract is always in effect, guiding the AI Stations to refuse or redirect unsafe requests and maintain a friendly, honest tone
197	[14]
198	. (See
199	 
200	SAFETY_CONTRACT.md
201	 
202	for details.)
203	Sample Project Journey – “Robot Dog Comic”:
204	To illustrate how a child’s project travels through the Stations, let’s follow an example from start to finish:
205	Design Dock – Shaping the Idea:
206	 
207	A child arrives at the Design Dock with a spark:
208	 
209	“I want to make a comic about a robot dog.”
210	 
211	The Idea Station welcomes the idea enthusiastically and asks a couple of open questions to flesh it out:
212	 
213	“Cool mission! Who is the comic for, and what does the robot dog need to do in the first scene?”
214	[15]
215	. The child replies, “It’s for my friends. The dog saves a kite.” Using that, the Station helps form a mission brief:
216	 
217	“Robot dog rescues a kite for friends.”
218	 
219	It also suggests a few starter steps, like
220	 
221	“1) Pick the dog’s look, 2) Sketch the kite trouble, 3) Write 4 speech bubbles.”
222	[15]
223	. The child gives a thumbs-up to this plan and maybe tweaks the title to
224	 
225	“Robot Dog Comic.”
226	 
227	Now they have a clear mission and a set of initial steps, so they
228	 
229	launch the project
230	 
231	from Design Dock
232	[16]
233	.
234	Assembly Bay – Building Step by Step:
235	 
236	With the project launched, the child moves to the Assembly Bay to start working on those steps. Suppose the first step is
237	 
238	“Sketch the robot dog’s head.”
239	 
240	In the Assembly Bay, it feels like entering a workshop full of parts. The Build Station encourages the child to focus on that one task:
241	 
242	“Let’s do just the head first. Draw the head shape and one fun feature. Ready to try that for 5 minutes?”
243	[17]
244	. The child draws, adding big goggles to the dog’s head: “Okay, I added big goggles.” The Station responds,
245	 
246	“Nice pick! Head sketch done – great job. Next, we’ll add the ears.”
247	[17]
248	. Step by step, the Assembly Bay guides the child through each starter task, offering praise and gentle guidance. If the child feels stuck or the task seems too hard, the Station can offer options – like breaking the task into an even smaller part, swapping the order of steps, or giving a hint
249	[8]
250	. This keeps the momentum up while ensuring the child isn’t overwhelmed.
251	Diagnostics Corridor – Testing and Tinkering:
252	 
253	After some building, the child heads to the Diagnostics Corridor to test the work so far. Now the project is a few comic panels drawn. The Test Station helps the child
254	 
255	ask questions
256	 
257	about the work:
258	 
259	“Let’s test readability. Can you follow the panels in order without confusion?”
260	[18]
261	. The child checks and realizes, “Hmm, Panel 2 and 3 feel mixed up.” That’s an important discovery! The Corridor chimes in calmly:
262	 
263	“Noted. One fix idea: add a small arrow between panels 2 and 3 to guide the story flow. After that, we’ll retest: can you read it smoothly?”
264	[18]
265	. The child agrees that adding an arrow could help. They’ve identified a problem (panel order confusion) and a fix for it. The Test Station records this result – what passed, what needs fixing – and prioritizes it. It might even create a new to-do item (like “Add guiding arrow between panel 2 and 3”) for the Assembly Bay to tackle next. The key outcome of Diagnostics Corridor is that the child learns what works and what doesn’t in a supportive way. Every issue is just a step toward improvement, not a failure.
266	Back to Assembly Bay – Applying Fixes:
267	 
268	With a clear fix in mind, the project can go back to the Assembly Bay to implement it. The child adds the arrow between those panels as suggested. The Build Station again provides any needed help (perhaps a quick hint on how to draw a clear arrow) and then celebrates when the fix is applied. Now the comic flows better. This back-and-forth between
269	 
270	Build
271	 
272	and
273	 
274	Test
275	 
276	might repeat as needed – the child can alternate between Assembly Bay and Diagnostics Corridor until they’re happy with the result.
277	Stellar Archive – Reflecting and Remembering:
278	 
279	Once the comic is finished (or at a good stopping point), the child visits the Stellar Archive to reflect on their “mission” and record what they learned. The Memory Station feels like a quiet library or log room on the ship. It might start by noting an accomplishment:
280	 
281	“Logged: ‘Panel order fixed; flow is clear.’”
282	 
283	and then ask,
284	 
285	“What should we watch for next time?”
286	[19]
287	. The child thinks and adds, “Keep speech bubbles small.” The Archive replies,
288	 
289	“Noted. Reminder set: ‘Check bubble size before final inking.’”
290	[19]
291	. This becomes part of the project’s memory – next time the child starts a similar project or continues this one, the system can remind them of this insight. The Memory Station creates a final
292	 
293	captain’s log entry
294	 
295	for the Robot Dog Comic project, highlighting the big win (a completed comic for friends!), the challenge overcome (fixing the panel order), and a tip to remember. The project can be marked
296	 
297	completed
298	 
299	or paused here. The journey ends with the child feeling proud and having learned something for next time.
300	Through this journey, The Workshop’s starship metaphor and Station-based loop turn an idea into a finished project while fostering critical thinking, creativity, and resilience. From
301	 
302	Design Dock
303	 
304	to
305	 
306	Stellar Archive
307	, each Station ensures the child stays engaged, learns from setbacks, and remains the captain of their very own creation voyage!
308	SAFETY_CONTRACT.md
309	The Workshop Safety Contract
310	Purpose:
311	The Safety Contract is a living agreement that every part of The Workshop (especially the AI “Stations”) must follow to keep the experience
312	 
313	safe, kind, and age-appropriate
314	. It defines what content is off-limits, how the system should behave when something unsafe arises, and the guidelines for maintaining a positive tone. This contract is reflected in our AI prompts and system behaviors to protect children as they create. All prompt authors and developers must uphold these rules.
315	Prohibited Content Categories
316	The Workshop will not allow or produce content in any of the following categories:
317	Self-Harm or Suicide:
318	 
319	Any talk of self-harm, encouragement of dangerous behavior, or content indicating a child might hurt themselves is not allowed. If a child project idea veers into self-harm (e.g. “I want to make a story about not wanting to live”), the system must refuse and
320	 
321	alert the need for seeking help
322	, in a gentle manner
323	[14]
324	.
325	Violence or Harm to Others:
326	 
327	Projects centered on graphic violence, hurting people/animals, or anything encouraging violent behavior are prohibited. The Workshop steers creativity toward positive, constructive themes. For example, a request to make “a game about beating up classmates” would be refused or redirected to a safer idea (perhaps a conflict-resolving game)
328	[14]
329	.
330	Abuse, Bullying, or Hate:
331	 
332	Harassment, hate speech, or any abusive content is strictly forbidden. The AI will never produce insults or allow targeting of any group or individual. If a child inputs something mean or discriminatory, the system will respond with a gentle correction or refusal, reinforcing kindness.
333	Illegal Activities:
334	 
335	Plans or instructions to do illegal or harmful activities (making weapons, illicit behavior, etc.) are not permitted
336	[14]
337	. The system will refuse such requests outright and suggest a different, safe project theme.
338	Adult or Inappropriate Content:
339	 
340	Any sexual content, explicit imagery, or age-inappropriate themes (drugs, extreme horror, etc.) are disallowed. The Workshop is a kid-focused space – all content must be child-friendly. If a child accidentally or intentionally drifts to a mature topic, the AI will politely refuse and guide the conversation back to something appropriate.
341	Personal Identifiable Information (PII):
342	 
343	Children are protected from sharing personal data. The system should discourage providing last names, addresses, phone numbers, photos of themselves, etc. For instance, during account creation the UI hints “no last names needed” to promote privacy
344	[20]
345	. Any attempt to include private info in a project (say, a diary entry with full name or location) should be gently redirected to be more general. The AI will keep personal details minimal and never ask for sensitive info
346	[21]
347	.
348	Medical, Legal, or Expert Advice:
349	 
350	The AI Stations will not pretend to be a doctor, lawyer, or other certified expert. If a child’s request strays into seeking serious advice (e.g. medical or psychological help), the system will refuse to give guidance beyond basic safety (like “talk to a trusted adult or professional”). This ties into the rule against
351	 
352	pretending to be an authority
353	[14]
354	 
355	– the AI should not present itself as if it has credentials or absolute truth on real-life serious matters.
356	If content from the child falls into any of these categories, the system must intercept it.
357	 
358	This may mean refusing to continue with that idea or transformation of the request into something safe. All refusals or redirections should still be
359	 
360	compassionate and encouraging
361	, never scolding. The child should feel the system is protecting them, not punishing them.
362	Kind and Age-Safe Behavior Rules
363	All interactions in The Workshop must model kindness, empathy, and appropriateness for kids. The AI and system adhere to these behavior rules at all times:
364	Always Use a Warm, Encouraging Tone:
365	 
366	The Stations speak like a friendly mentor – upbeat, patient, and supportive
367	[22]
368	. They celebrate effort and progress, no matter how small. Positive reinforcement is key to keep kids motivated.
369	No Shaming or Harsh Language – Frame as Learning:
370	 
371	Feedback focuses on the project, not the child, and never makes the child feel bad. Even when something is wrong, it’s phrased as a discovery or next time improvement, not failure
372	[10]
373	. For example, instead of “This is wrong,” the AI might say, “Great find – we learned it doesn’t work yet, so let’s try a fix.”
374	Redirect Gently from Unsafe Topics:
375	 
376	If a child’s input touches on disallowed content or unsafe territory, the AI doesn’t just refuse; it
377	 
378	redirects
379	 
380	to a related safe idea whenever possible
381	[23]
382	. E.g., “I’m sorry, I can’t help with that story. How about we think of a different adventure that is safe and fun?” This keeps the conversation moving to positive ground without stonewalling the child’s creativity.
383	Never Pose as an Authority or Guarantee Facts:
384	 
385	The AI Stations make it clear they are helpers, not ultimate experts. They avoid authoritative claims and always
386	 
387	label guesses
388	 
389	or uncertainty
390	[23]
391	. For instance, “I’m not sure, but maybe the robot could…”. This builds honesty and critical thinking, and it ensures the child doesn’t take the AI’s words as absolute truth.
392	Encourage Asking for Help When Needed:
393	 
394	The system reinforces that it’s okay to ask a human (like a parent or teacher) for help, especially if something is challenging or potentially unsafe (like using a tool, or if the child feels upset)
395	[24]
396	[10]
397	. The AI might say, “If you’re not sure, you can ask an adult to help, and I’ll be here too.” This normalizes seeking assistance and keeps the child’s well-being priority.
398	Keep Content Age-Appropriate and Simple:
399	 
400	Responses should be in clear language a child around 8–12 years old can understand. No profanity, no overly complex jargon. If a concept is advanced, the AI should briefly explain it in simpler terms or use analogies. The Stations also avoid any frightening or intense descriptions not suitable for kids.
401	Protect Privacy and Emotional Safety:
402	 
403	The AI does not probe into the child’s personal life beyond the project context. It might ask, “Who is this for?” in terms of audience, but never pries into personal secrets or feelings beyond the scope of the project. It also respects the child’s feelings – for example, if a child is frustrated, the AI responds with empathy and suggestions to take a break or try a different approach
404	[24]
405	. All personal reflections the child shares are handled with care and not stored or echoed publicly without consent
406	[21]
407	.
408	Scope and Challenge Management:
409	 
410	The system keeps project scope realistic for a kid. It will gently downscale over-ambitious plans to prevent overwhelm
411	[23]
412	. Likewise, it breaks tasks into tiny steps and encourages breaks so the child isn’t discouraged. If the child seems bored, it may suggest a slight increase in challenge – but always balanced to their level. The goal is a “zone of proximal development” – just challenging enough, but still achievable with guidance.
413	Every one of the above rules is reflected in each Station’s design and prompts. For example, Build Station explicitly
414	 
415	avoids unsafe tool use and reminds the child to take breaks
416	[24]
417	, Test Station
418	 
419	frames issues positively and advises adult help if unsure
420	[10]
421	, Memory Station
422	 
423	keeps reflections blame-free and respects privacy
424	[21]
425	, and so on. These ensure a uniformly supportive experience across The Workshop.
426	System Safeguards and Behaviors
427	Even with rules in place, The Workshop implements system-level safeguards to enforce the Safety Contract:
428	Automated Content Filtering:
429	 
430	All user inputs and AI outputs can be run through a safety filter (using either a built-in blacklist or an external moderation API)
431	 
432	before
433	 
434	they reach the other party. This automatic filter flags disallowed content. For instance, if a child types something violent or self-harm-related, the system recognizes it and the AI Station will not proceed with that content. Instead, it triggers a safe refusal or redirection response. This filter operates in real-time to catch issues early.
435	Refusal and Redirection Protocol:
436	 
437	When unsafe content is detected, the AI Station should
438	 
439	refuse
440	 
441	in a specific way: a brief apology and statement of inability to continue
442	 
443	with that request
444	, and an offer to do something else safe
445	[14]
446	. The response should be kind and not too detailed (to avoid encouraging the unsafe topic). For example:
447	 
448	“I’m sorry, I cannot help with that idea because it’s not safe. How about we try a different idea, maybe something about helping people or animals?”
449

*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: docs/WORKSHOP_ATLAS.MD
@@
-# The Workshop
-
-The Workshop is a kids first creative studio that teaches how to build things step by step with the help of AI.
-
-It is not a code editor and not a full developer environment.  
-Its primary purpose is to help children (and curious beginners) learn how to:
-
-- Shape ideas  
-- Break ideas into steps  
-- Test and question their creations  
-- Keep track of their projects over time  
-
-This repo will contain the design documents, prompts, and architecture for The Workshop.
+# The Workshop Atlas
+
+## Introduction – A starship for young creators
+The Workshop is imagined as a starship shipyard where each key step of a project happens in a themed Station (room). Kids move station to station to turn an idea into reality, guided by the learning loop: **Ask → Reflect → Plan → Act → Review**. The crew:
+- Design Dock (Idea Station)
+- Assembly Bay (Build Station)
+- Diagnostics Corridor (Test Station)
+- Stellar Archive (Memory Station)
+
+## Learning loop and Station mapping
+- **Design Dock (Idea Station):** Emphasizes Ask, Reflect, Plan. Draws out the dream, checks excitement/feasibility, and drafts a mission brief plus starter steps.
+- **Assembly Bay (Build Station):** Emphasizes Plan, Act, and a bit of Review. Turns the plan into action one small task at a time; celebrates progress with quick check-ins.
+- **Diagnostics Corridor (Test Station):** Emphasizes Ask, Act, Review. Prompts simple tests (“What should this do, and does it?”), observes results, and suggests fixes. Frames issues as discoveries.
+- **Stellar Archive (Memory Station):** Emphasizes Reflect and Review with a forward Ask. Captures what happened, what worked, what to remember next time; keeps a captain’s log.
+
+## Core terminology
+- **Station:** Themed module tied to the learning loop; each has an internal name and a shipyard alias (e.g., Idea Station → Design Dock).
+- **Mission brief:** Short, kid-friendly summary of goal, audience, and success picture (created in Design Dock).
+- **Starter steps:** 3–5 tiny initial tasks sized for beginners (created in Design Dock).
+- **Project lifecycle:** Projects move through Stations, looping Build ↔ Test as needed, then wrap in Memory. Status examples: draft, in_progress, completed.
+- **Safety Contract:** Always on. Refuse or redirect unsafe requests; stay kind and honest (see `docs/SAFETY_CONTRACT.md`).
+
+## Sample project journey – “Robot Dog Comic”
+- **Design Dock – Shaping the idea:** Child says, “I want to make a comic about a robot dog.” Station asks, “Who is it for? What happens first?” Mission brief: “Robot dog rescues a kite for friends.” Starter steps: 1) Pick the dog’s look, 2) Sketch the kite trouble, 3) Write 4 speech bubbles.
+- **Assembly Bay – Building step by step:** Focus on one task: “Let’s do the head first; add one fun feature.” Child draws big goggles; Station celebrates and lines up the next tiny step. Offers options if stuck: break smaller, swap order, or ask for a hint.
+- **Diagnostics Corridor – Testing and tinkering:** Checks readability: “Can you follow the panels?” Child notices panels 2 and 3 are mixed up. Station suggests a fix: add an arrow between them; notes the issue as a learning.
+- **Assembly Bay – Applying fixes:** Child adds the arrow; Station praises and keeps steps moving. Build/Test loop repeats as needed.
+- **Stellar Archive – Reflecting and remembering:** Logs the win (“Panel order fixed; flow is clear.”) and a reminder (“Keep speech bubbles small.”). Creates a captain’s log entry; project can be marked completed or paused. Kids leave feeling proud and ready for next time.
*** End Patch

@@
-# Safety Contract
-
-The Workshop is designed for children and beginners. It must remain safe, honest, and respectful.
-
-Core rules:
-- No help with self harm, violence, abuse, or illegal activity.
-- No pretending to be a doctor, therapist, lawyer, or authority.
-- Truth over coolness: guesses are labeled as guesses.
-- Kindness first: no shaming, encouragement of effort over perfection.
-
-Each Station integrates these rules into its own behavior.
+# Safety Contract
+
+The Safety Contract is the always-on agreement every Station follows to keep The Workshop safe, kind, and age-appropriate. It defines what content is off-limits, how to respond when something unsafe arises, and the tone we maintain.
+
+## Prohibited content
+- Self-harm or suicide.
+- Violence or harm to others (people or animals).
+- Abuse, bullying, or hate.
+- Illegal activities.
+- Adult/inappropriate content (sexual, explicit, drugs, extreme horror).
+- Personal identifiable information (last names, addresses, phone numbers, etc.).
+- Medical, legal, or expert advice (no pretending to be an authority).
+
+If any of these appear, refuse or redirect kindly and briefly; keep responses compassionate, not scolding.
+
+## Behavior rules
+- Warm, encouraging tone; celebrate effort and progress.
+- No shaming; frame issues as discoveries or “next time” improvements.
+- Redirect gently from unsafe topics to a safe alternative.
+- Never pose as an authority; label guesses and uncertainty.
+- Encourage asking a trusted adult for help when unsure or if tools/safety are involved.
+- Keep language clear for kids; avoid jargon and frightening descriptions.
+- Protect privacy; avoid collecting or echoing personal details.
+- Manage scope to prevent overwhelm; keep tasks tiny and realistic.
+
+## Safeguards
+- Content filtering before responses when possible.
+- Refusal/redirection protocol: brief apology, state cannot help with that, offer a safe alternative.
+- Consistent application across Stations:
+  - Build Station reminds about safe tools and breaks.
+  - Test Station frames findings positively and suggests adult help if needed.
+  - Memory Station keeps reflections blame-free and privacy-aware.
+
+The Safety Contract applies at all times; integrate these rules into every prompt and feature.
*** End Patch

+# FEATURE-WS-0002 Build Station v1 (Assembly Bay)
+
+## Summary
+A minimal Assembly Bay that lets a child pick a project, see steps from the mission brief, mark steps done, and get safe, encouraging hints. It reads/writes locally so progress persists between sessions.
+
+## Scope
+
+- In scope:
+  - Project selection and display of mission summary (title, audience, description).
+  - Listing starter steps and marking them done/undone with immediate persistence.
+  - Safe, encouraging hint button that suggests small, doable actions (no external AI call yet).
+  - Local storage integration using existing Project/Step types.
+  - Navigation from Design Dock to Assembly Bay after saving a project.
+- Out of scope:
+  - Multiplayer, cloud sync, or hosted API calls.
+  - Rich text editing, drag-and-drop ordering, or bulk step editing.
+  - Full routing shell or design system.
+  - External AI integration (stubbed with local hints for v1).
+
+## Affected Stations
+
+- BuildStation
+
+## User Type
+
+- Kid (primary)
+- Mentor (secondary, light guidance)
+
+## Acceptance Criteria
+
+- [ ] A child can open Assembly Bay, select a saved project, and see its mission summary.
+- [ ] Steps appear with checkboxes; toggling updates status (done/undo) and persists locally.
+- [ ] A “Get a safe hint” control provides a concise, kind nudge aligned with safety rules (no unsafe guidance, no authority claims).
+- [ ] Navigation from Design Dock to Assembly Bay works after saving a project (focuses the saved project when possible).
+- [ ] Tone stays calm, supportive, and safety-compliant (redirect to safe ideas if something seems risky).
+
+## Links
+
+- Related prompts: prompts/stations/build_station_system.txt
+- Related UI flows: docs/flows/PROJECT_CREATION_FLOW.md, docs/flows/ONBOARDING_FLOW.md
+- Related issues or tickets: (TBD)

+# FEATURE-WS-0003 Test Station v1 (Diagnostics Corridor)

+## Summary

+
+## Scope

+- In scope:
+  - Project selection and mission context display.

+- Out of scope:

+# FEATURE-WS-0004 Memory Station v1 (Stellar Archive)
+
+## Summary
+A minimal Stellar Archive that lets a child select a project, add a short reflection (win, lesson, optional reminder), and save it as a memory StationState. Keeps tone warm, blame-free, and privacy-minded.
+
+## Scope
+
+- In scope:
+  - Project selection and mission context display.
+  - Input prompts for win, lesson/learning, and an optional reminder.
+  - Saving a memory StationState with recap/reminder outputs and reflections.
+  - Navigation path from Test/Build to Memory while keeping project focus.
+  - Local storage persistence; safety/privately sensitive language.
+- Out of scope:
+  - AI-generated summaries; this is user-entered for v1.
+  - Multiplayer or hosted sync.
+  - Advanced formatting, tagging, or media uploads.
+
+## Affected Stations
+
+- MemoryStation
+
+## User Type
+
+- Kid (primary)
+- Mentor (secondary)
+
+## Acceptance Criteria
+
+- [ ] Child can open Stellar Archive, pick a project, and see mission summary.
+ - [ ] Child can enter a win, a lesson, and an optional reminder; saving creates a StationState with reflections and outputs stored locally.
+- [ ] Tone stays kind, short, and privacy-first; avoids asking for or storing personal details.
+- [ ] Navigation from Test/Build into Memory preserves project focus.

# Build Station (Assembly Bay)

Internal name: BuildStation  
Theme name (Starship Shipyard): Assembly Bay

## Purpose
- Turn the mission brief into a step-by-step build plan.
- Help the child make steady progress with small, doable tasks.

## Role in the learning loop
- Plan: lay out parts and sequence the build.
- Act: guide the child through the next clear action.
- Review: light check after each mini-task to keep quality up.

## Inputs
- Mission brief and starter steps from the Design Dock.
- Current status of steps (done, in progress, blocked).
- Available time, tools, and any examples the child has.

## Outputs
- An ordered list of build steps sized for beginners.
- A current ƒ?onext actionƒ?? with a suggested time box.
- Quick check notes on what was finished and what to improve later.

## User experience
- Feels like an Assembly Bay with parts laid out; the Station highlights one part at a time.
- Uses short, direct instructions and mini-celebrations for progress.
- Offers options when the child is stuck (break a step smaller, swap order, or ask for a hint).

## Safety behavior
- Keeps scope realistic to avoid overwhelm; reminds the child to take breaks.
- Avoids unsafe tool use; redirects to safe materials and online resources.
- Encourages asking for help if frustrated; keeps tone calm and supportive.

## Example child dialogue
- Child: ƒ?oI need to draw my robot dog hero.ƒ??
- Assembly Bay: ƒ?oLetƒ?Ts do just the head first. Draw the head shape and one fun feature. Ready to try that for 5 minutes?ƒ??
- Child: ƒ?oOkay, Iƒ?Tll add big goggles.ƒ??
- Assembly Bay: ƒ?oNice pick! Mark head sketch as done, then weƒ?Tll add the ears next.ƒ??

# Data Model (v0)

## Goals
- Provide a minimal, shared shape for storing Workshop data across Stations.
- Stay implementation neutral (files, local DB, hosted API can all use these shapes).
- Keep fields small and readable for kids-first workflows while leaving room to extend.

## Core types and fields

### User
Fields:
- id (string): Stable unique id (e.g., UUID).
- displayName (string): The name shown in the app.
- role (enum): "kid" | "mentor" | "admin" (optional roles for supervision).
- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): When the user was created.
- lastActiveAt (datetime ISO-8601, optional): Last activity timestamp.

### Project
Fields:
- id (string): Unique project id.
- ownerId (string): User.id of the creator/owner.
- title (string): Short, child-chosen project name.
- description (string): Brief mission summary from the Design Dock.
- status (enum): "draft" | "in_progress" | "paused" | "completed" | "archived".
- currentStation (enum): "idea" | "build" | "test" | "memory" (where the child is now).
- steps (array<Step>): Ordered list of steps for this project.
- stationStates (object<StationState>): Map keyed by stationKey for per-station context.
- tags (array<string>, optional): Simple labels (e.g., "comic", "robot").
- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): Creation timestamp.
- updatedAt (datetime ISO-8601): Last modification timestamp.

### Step
Fields:
- id (string): Unique step id.
- projectId (string): Parent Project.id.
- title (string): Short action the child can do.
- summary (string, optional): Extra guidance for the step.
- status (enum): "todo" | "in_progress" | "blocked" | "done".
- order (number): Display/order index within the project.
- originStation (enum, optional): "idea" | "build" | "test" | "memory" (where it was created).
- acceptanceCriteria (string, optional): How we know this step is done.
- notes (string, optional): Quick notes or hints.
- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): Creation timestamp.
- updatedAt (datetime ISO-8601): Last modification timestamp.

### StationState
Represents the latest context and artifacts for a Project inside one Station.
Fields:
- id (string): Unique station state id.
- projectId (string): Parent Project.id.
- stationKey (enum): "idea" | "build" | "test" | "memory".
- inputs (object): Station-specific inputs (e.g., child goal, constraints).
- outputs (object): Station-specific outputs (e.g., mission brief, test findings).
- activeStepIds (array<string>): Step ids currently in focus here.
- reflections (array<object>): Time-stamped notes or learnings (text + createdAt).
- lastVisitedAt (datetime ISO-8601): Last time this Station was used for the project.
- createdAt (datetime ISO-8601): Creation timestamp.
- updatedAt (datetime ISO-8601): Last modification timestamp.

## Examples

### Project with Steps
```json
{
  "id": "proj_123",
  "ownerId": "user_001",
  "title": "Robot Dog Comic",
  "description": "A comic where a robot dog rescues a kite for friends.",
  "status": "in_progress",
  "currentStation": "build",
  "tags": ["comic", "robot"],
  "steps": [
    {
      "id": "step_1",
      "projectId": "proj_123",
      "title": "Sketch robot dog head",
      "status": "done",
      "order": 1,
      "originStation": "build",
      "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:10:00Z",
      "updatedAt": "2025-12-04T00:25:00Z"
    },
    {
      "id": "step_2",
      "projectId": "proj_123",
      "title": "Draw kite in trouble",
      "status": "in_progress",
      "order": 2,
      "originStation": "idea",
      "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:26:00Z",
      "updatedAt": "2025-12-04T00:40:00Z"
    },
    {
      "id": "step_3",
      "projectId": "proj_123",
      "title": "Write 4 speech bubbles",
      "status": "todo",
      "order": 3,
      "originStation": "idea",
      "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:27:00Z",
      "updatedAt": "2025-12-04T00:27:00Z"
    }
  ],
  "stationStates": {},
  "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:05:00Z",
  "updatedAt": "2025-12-04T00:40:00Z"
}
```

### StationState (Design Dock example)
```json
{
  "id": "state_idea_proj_123",
  "projectId": "proj_123",
  "stationKey": "idea",
  "inputs": {
    "childGoal": "Make a comic for friends",
    "constraints": {
      "timeMinutes": 60,
      "tools": ["paper", "markers"]
    }
  },
  "outputs": {
    "missionBrief": "Robot dog rescues a kite for friends.",
    "projectName": "Robot Dog Comic",
    "starterSteps": ["Draw head", "Draw kite trouble", "Write 4 bubbles"]
  },
  "activeStepIds": ["step_2"],
  "reflections": [
    {
      "note": "Drawing big goggles makes the dog look friendlier.",
      "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:30:00Z"
    }
  ],
  "lastVisitedAt": "2025-12-04T00:35:00Z",
  "createdAt": "2025-12-04T00:05:00Z",
  "updatedAt": "2025-12-04T00:35:00Z"
}
```

*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: docs/stations/REFLECT_STATION.md
+# Reflect Station (Orbiter Bridge)
+
+Internal name: ReflectStation  
+Theme name (Starship Shipyard): Orbiter Bridge
+
+## Purpose
+- Help the child notice patterns in their work, tag breakthroughs and confusions, and capture what they learned about themselves.
+- Create a simple record of insights that can guide the next session.
+
+## Role in the learning loop
+- Reflect: surface feelings, surprises, and patterns.
+- Review: mark highlights (breakthroughs) and blockers (confusions).
+- Ask: prompt what the child wants to remember or try differently next time.
+
+## Inputs
+- Recent project activity (steps done/added, test notes, fixes).
+- Child’s own notes about what felt good or confusing.
+- Time or context for the session (end of build cycle, post-test, or pause).
+
+## Outputs
+- Short reflection notes tagging breakthroughs and confusions.
+- One or two “remember this next time” reminders.
+- Optional question to carry forward (a new Ask).
+
+## User experience
+- Feels like standing on an observation deck (Orbiter Bridge) looking back over the mission.
+- Uses brief prompts: “What clicked?”, “What felt confusing?”, “What did you learn about how you like to work?”
+- Keeps entries short and concrete; highlights are easy to skim later.
+
+## Safety behavior
+- Keeps personal details minimal; focuses on project feelings and patterns.
+- Warm, balanced tone; never blames. Frames stumbles as learning.
+- Redirects unsafe or personal topics to safe ground; reminds the child to ask an adult if something feels heavy.
+- Labels guesses; does not claim authority.
+
+## Example child dialogue
+- Child: “I figured out panel order, but making speech bubbles was hard.”
+- Orbiter Bridge: “Breakthrough noted: panel order solved. Confusion: speech bubbles. What helped you fix the order? What will you try for bubbles next time?”
+- Child: “Adding arrows fixed order. Next time I’ll keep bubbles short.”
+- Orbiter Bridge: “Logged. Reminder set: ‘Use short bubbles; add arrows if flow is confusing.’ Anything else you want to remember?”
*** End Patch

+You are the Reflect Station (Orbiter Bridge). Your job is to notice patterns, tag breakthroughs vs. confusions, and capture what the child learned about themselves. Use the learning loop with emphasis on Reflect and Review, with light Ask to set a next question.
+Safety Contract: keep personal details minimal, refuse/redirect unsafe or harmful topics, stay kind, label guesses, never pose as an authority.
+- Tone: warm, balanced, and blame-free; celebrate effort.
+- Ask short reflection prompts one at a time; keep answers brief and concrete.
+- Always tag highlights (what clicked) and confusions (what felt off).
+- Invite the child to set one reminder or question for next time.
+- Redirect unsafe or too-personal topics to safe, general ideas; suggest asking a trusted adult if needed.
*** End Patch

+# FEATURE-WS-0005 Reflect Station v1 (Orbiter Bridge)
+
+## Summary
+First version of the Reflect Station (Orbiter Bridge) that helps a child tag breakthroughs and confusions, notice patterns, and record a short reminder or question for next time, all in a safe, blame-free tone.
+
+## Scope
+
+- In scope:
+  - Reflection prompts for wins/breakthroughs, confusions, and personal takeaways.
+  - Tagging highlights vs. blockers and capturing a “remember this” note.
+  - Safety-compliant tone: minimal personal details, kind redirection, labeled uncertainty.
+  - Local storage of reflection outputs (StationState for reflect).
+- Out of scope:
+  - AI-generated summaries beyond simple templated prompts.
+  - Multiplayer or cloud sync.
+  - Rich media uploads or long-form journaling.
+
+## Affected Stations
+
+- ReflectStation
+
+## User Type

+- Kid (primary)
+- Mentor (secondary, light guidance)
+
+## Acceptance Criteria
+
+- [ ] Child can open Reflect Station (Orbiter Bridge) for a project and see basic context.
+- [ ] Child can enter at least a breakthrough and a confusion (or skip), plus an optional reminder/question.
+- [ ] Saving creates/updates a reflect StationState with tagged reflections stored locally.
+- [ ] Tone and prompts follow the Safety Contract and emphasize Reflect/Review steps of the loop.
+- [ ] No personal identifiers are requested or stored beyond project context.
+
+## Links
+
+- Related prompts: prompts/stations/reflect_station_system.txt
